description: Procedure to remove gallbladder due to gallstones in a female patient. Anesthesia administered and incision made in the abdomen. Gallbladder removed and incision closed. Patient monitored post-surgery.
transcription: Patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of cholelithiasis. She presents with right upper quadrant pain and is found to have multiple gallstones. The decision is made to proceed with cholecystectomy. The patient is taken to the operating room and anesthesia is administered. A midline incision is made and the abdomen is insufflated with air. The gallbladder is identified and a T-tube is placed. The gallbladder is then dissected free from the liver bed and the cystic duct and artery are clipped and divided. The gallbladder is removed and the bed is inspected for any bleeding. The incision is closed in layers with absorbable sutures. The patient is monitored post-operatively and discharged on post-operative day 3.

description: Procedure for removal of thyroid gland due to goiter. Postoperative instructions provided.
transcription: PATIENT: 62 year old F with a history of a goiter. Exam under anesthesia showed a right lobe goiter, 7cm in greatest dimension, firm and immobile. Biopsy was benign. Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Indication: large goiter causing compressive symptoms. Surgical procedure: right hemithyroidectomy with isthmusectomy. Estimated blood loss: 50cc. Operative time: 120 minutes. Postoperative course: patient was extubated in the operating room and transferred to the recovery room in stable condition. Vital signs were stable. She was transferred to the floor. Her postoperative course was uncomplicated. She was discharged home on postoperative day 3.

description: Procedure for removal of inguinal hernia in a male patient using the open technique. Consent obtained and anesthesia administered. Incision made and hernia sac dissected and extracted. Suture closure and dressing applied.
transcription: Procedure for removal of inguinal hernia in a male patient using the open technique. Consent obtained and anesthesia administered. Incision made and hernia sac dissected and extracted. Suture closure and dressing applied.

description: Procedure performed to remove a tumor from the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Patient did well post-op.
transcription: Preop: 82 year old female with a 4cm mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Workup: CAT scan of the abdomen shows a 4cm mass in Segment IV of the liver. Consultation: Gastroenterology for possible biliary tract involvement. Hepatology: No history of hepatitis or cirrhosis. Surgery: Right hepatectomy. Postop: 82 year old female in the surgical intensive care unit following right hepatectomy for a 4cm mass in Segment IV of the liver. The operative time was 127 minutes. Estimated blood loss was 500cc. The patient is intubated and receiving oxygen by face mask at 2 liters per minute. The urinary catheter drains 150cc since surgery. The nasogastric tube was removed in the recovery room. The diet will be advanced as tolerated. The drainage from the right subhepatic drainage tube is serous with no bile. The drainage from the right subhepatic biliary drainage tube is bile-stained. The wound is dry. The patient is sedated and receiving intermittent intravenous morphine for pain.
sample_name: Right Hepatectomy for Mass in Segment IV

description: Procedure performed by a surgeon to remove a tumor from a patient's breast.
transcription: [Patient Name] presented with a [Size] cm [Type] tumor in her left breast. The patient underwent a left simple mastectomy with axillary node dissection. Pathology revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, Grade 2, Estrogen Receptor Positive, Progesterone Receptor Positive, HER2 Negative. The final pathology stage was pT2N0M0.
sample_name: Left Simple Mastectomy with Axillary Node Dissection

description: Surgical procedure for removal of a benign mass from the breast using a lumpectomy technique.
transcription: PATIENT: Age 55, presents with a palpable right breast mass. Mammogram and ultrasound performed in October 2017 show a 1.7 x 1.4 cm hypoechoic mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Biopsy performed in November 2017 shows a benign phyllodes tumor. Patient presents today for removal of the mass. SURGEON: Allergies: NKDA. Meds: Synthroid, levothyroxine, metformin, simvastatin, aspirin, lisinopril. Review of systems is otherwise negative. PAST SURGERY: Cholecystectomy, hysterectomy. FAMILY HX: Mother with osteoporosis, father with Alzheimer's. SMOKING: Never. DRINK: Occasional. NARRATIVE OF PROCEDURE: Patient is taken to the OR and given general anesthesia. She is prepped and draped in the usual fashion. A 2 cm incision is made in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Dissection is carried down to the mass, which is easily identified. The mass is removed en bloc. The bed is irrigated and closed in a standard fashion. The patient is awakened and taken to the PACU.

description: Procedure for removal of gallbladder due to gallstones.
transcription: Time: 11:00 AM. Patient: 47 year old female. Allergies: Nil. Procedure: Cholecystectomy. Indication: Cholelithiasis. Anesthesia: General. Surgeon: Dr. Smith. Surgical Assist: Nurse. Nursing Staff: Nurses. Duration: 90 minutes. Estimated Blood Loss: 50 ml. Closure: Subcuticular closure of port sites. Dressings: Sterile dressings. Postoperative Care: 1. Monitor for signs of infection, fever, and bile leak. 2. Maintain nothing per oral (NPO) status. 3. Administer antibiotics. 4. Monitor for signs of bleeding. 5. Monitor for signs of anastomotic leak. 6. Monitor for signs of jaundice. 7. Monitor for signs of pancreatitis. 8. Monitor for signs of wound infection. 9. Monitor for signs of hernia formation. 10. Monitor for signs of sepsis. 11. Monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 12. Monitor for signs of pulmonary embolism (PE). 13. Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias. 14. Monitor for signs of respiratory distress. 15. Monitor for signs of renal insufficiency. 16. Monitor for signs of delirium. 17. Monitor for signs of neurocognitive disorders. 18. Monitor for signs of anemia. 19. Monitor for signs of malnutrition. 20. Monitor for signs of dehydration. 21. Monitor for signs of electrolyte imbalance. 22. Monitor for signs of acute kidney injury (AKI). 23. Monitor for signs of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 24. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated acute kidney injury (AKI). 25. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 26. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated delirium. 27. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated neurocognitive disorders. 28. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated anemia. 29. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated malnutrition. 30. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated dehydration. 31. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated electrolyte imbalance. 32. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated acute kidney injury (AKI). 33. Monitor for signs of sepsis-associated acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
sample_name: Cholecystectomy Procedure for Removal of Gallbladder

description: Summary of patient's medical history and physical examination.
transcription: Patient presents with a 2-week history of cough and shortness of breath. Denies fever, chills, or night sweats. No recent travel or sick contacts. Smoker with 20 pack-year history. Denies alcohol or drug use. BP 140/80, HR 90, RR 18. Mild tachypnea. Clear lungs and heart sounds. Abdomen benign. Extremities warm and pulses intact.
sample_name: Consultation for Cough and Shortness of Breath

description: Summary of medical history and physical examination.
transcription: Patient presents with a 2-week history of intermittent abdominal pain. Pain is located in the left lower quadrant and is associated with bloating and flatulence. Bowel movements are frequent, but there is a sense of incomplete evacuation. Patient denies fevers, chills, or weight loss. Medical history is significant for hypertension, which is well-controlled on medication. The patient's mother had colon cancer at age 70. Physical examination reveals mild left lower quadrant tenderness. Rectal exam shows no masses or bleeding. Rest of exam is unremarkable.

description: Patient presents with chronic lower back pain.
transcription: Patient is a 55-year-old male, employed as a construction worker, who presents with chronic lower back pain. Symptoms began 6 months ago and are described as a dull ache in the lumbar region, worsened with prolonged sitting and lifting. No radicular symptoms are present. The patient denies any history of trauma or accidental injury to the back. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, both well-controlled on medication. Medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. Allergies are to penicillin. Family history is significant for colon cancer in the father. Social history is negative for tobacco and alcohol use. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies include a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, both within normal limits. Spine radiographs are scheduled. The patient is referred to physical therapy for core strengthening.
sample_name: New Patient Consult - History and Phy.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath.
transcription: Patient: Good morning, doctor. I've been having some chest pain and shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Doctor: Alright, let's have a seat and we'll go through some questions. Can you describe the chest pain for me? Patient: Yes, it's a tightness, almost like someone's squeezing my chest. Doctor: And does it radiate anywhere else in your body? Patient: No, it's just in the chest. Doctor: And how often does it occur? Patient: It happens several times a day, usually after I've eaten. Doctor: And what about the shortness of breath? Patient: It happens when I'm lying down, and it feels like I can't catch my breath. Doctor: And has it gotten worse over time? Patient: Yes, it seems to be getting worse each day. Doctor: Alright, I'm going to examine you now and take some tests to determine the cause of your symptoms. Is there anything else you'd like to tell me before we begin?
sample_name: Chest Pain and Shortness of Breath Consultation.

description: Summary of medical history and physical examination conducted during a consultation.
transcription: Patient presents with a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath and dry cough. Symptoms are worse with exertion and lying down. Denies fevers, chills, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Past medical history includes hypertension and hypothyroidism, both well-controlled with medications. Surgical history is significant for appendectomy and cholecystectomy. Family history is negative. Social history is significant for tobacco use, 1 pack per day for 30 years, and alcohol use, 1-2 drinks per day. Medications include lisinopril, levothyroxine, and albuterol/ipratropium as needed. Vital signs are notable for a respiratory rate of 22 and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Exam is significant for bibasilar crackles and a right basilar infiltrate. Diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is considered.

description: Patient presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. Diagnosis of congestive heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Treatment with diuretics and oxygen therapy.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of dyspnea and chest pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG demonstrates sinus rhythm and no acute ST segment changes. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Pulmonary function tests reveal a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) of 45% and a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 60%. Echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 30%. Diagnosis of congestive heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Treatment with furosemide and oxygen therapy.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of shortness of breath and chest pain. Diagnosis is pulmonary embolism. Treatment includes anticoagulation therapy and oxygen therapy.
transcription: Patient presents today with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. Vitals are stable. The patient is in mild distress. Respiratory examination reveals bilateral crackles in the lower lobes. Chest X-ray shows a right middle lobe infiltrate. Pulmonary embolism is suspected and a CT scan is ordered. Results show a large pulmonary embolism in the right lower lobe. The patient is started on heparin and oxygen therapy.

description: Patient with a history of coronary artery disease presents with shortness of breath and chest pain. Diagnostic tests reveal pulmonary edema and decreased left ventricular function. Treatment includes medication for heart failure and arrhythmia management.
transcription: Patient is a 72-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He presents to the emergency department today complaining of shortness of breath and chest pain. His symptoms began 2 days ago, and he has not experienced any relief. He reports that his shortness of breath is worse with exertion and lying flat. He denies any cough, sputum production, or fever. His only medication is aspirin 81mg daily. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/85, pulse is 98, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Respiratory examination reveals bibasilar crackles. Cardiovascular examination is significant for an S3 and jugular venous distention. Laboratory studies reveal a BNP of 1200 pg/mL. ECG reveals an old inferior STEMI. Chest X-ray reveals pulmonary edema. Echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%. Patient is diagnosed with heart failure and admitted for further management.

description: Patient presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. Echocardiogram and pulmonary function tests were performed. Treatment with oxygen and diuretics was initiated. Follow-up appointments were scheduled.
transcription: Patient presented to the emergency department today with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient denied any other symptoms. The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of myocardial infarction in 2012. The patient's medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Vital signs are significant for a respiratory rate of 24, a blood pressure of 145/80, and an oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical exam is significant for a grade II/VI systolic murmur at the left sternal border. ECG shows sinus rhythm with a rate of 80, normal axis, and no acute ST segment changes. Laboratory studies are pending. Chest x-ray shows no acute changes. Echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%, a left atrium of 4.5 cm, and a normal left ventricular systolic function. Pulmonary function tests reveal a FEV1 of 60%, a FVC of 85%, and a FEV1/FVC ratio of 71%. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management. Oxygen was initiated via nasal cannula at 2 liters per minute. Diuretics were initiated for pulmonary edema. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the cardiologist and pulmonologist.

description: Patient presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. ECG showed ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Patient was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction and admitted for further management.
transcription: Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Labs are pending. ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Patient is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction and admitted for further management.

description: Patient presents with shortness of breath and chest pain. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dysfunction and pulmonary artery hypertension. Diagnosis: Heart failure with pulmonary artery hypertension.
transcription: Patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient is a 62 year old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.8 degrees Celsius, heart rate 96 beats per minute, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, blood pressure 130/70 millimeters of mercury, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Physical exam is significant for jugular venous distention to the angle of Louis, a grade 2/6 holodiastolic murmur at the left sternal border, and bilateral rales in the lung fields. Cardiac enzymes are negative. ECG shows sinus rhythm with a rate of 96 beats per minute and a left ventricular strain pattern. A stat head CT rules out acute cerebrovascular accident or acute intracranial bleed. Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and bilateral pulmonary edema. Echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%, a left ventricular end diastolic dimension of 5.5 centimeters, a left atrial diameter of 4.5 centimeters, and a right ventricular systolic pressure of 60 millimeters of mercury. BNP level is 1215 pg/mL. Diagnosis is heart failure with pulmonary artery hypertension. Patient is admitted for further management.
sample_name: Heart Failure with Pulmonary Artery Hypertension

description: Patient with history of coronary artery disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. Echocardiogram showed left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30%. Pulmonary function tests revealed a forced expiratory volume in 1 second of 50% of predicted. Patient was started on oxygen therapy and diuretics.
transcription: Patient is a 72-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presented to the emergency department today with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. Vital signs at presentation included a blood pressure of 140/80 mm Hg, pulse of 90 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Physical examination was significant for bibasilar crackles and 2+ lower extremity edema. Initial laboratory studies included a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and troponin I level, which were all unremarkable. An electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus rhythm with ST segment depressions in leads V2-V4. A chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly and bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. The patient was started on oxygen via nasal cannula and admitted to the cardiology service for further evaluation. Echocardiography revealed left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30%. Pulmonary function tests were significant for a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) of 50% of predicted. The patient was started on diuretics and continued on oxygen therapy. Cardiology was consulted for further management of the patient's coronary artery disease.
sample_name: Cardiovascular / Pulmonary - Shortness of Breath and Chest Pain

description: A 65-year-old male presents with shortness of breath and chest pain.
transcription: Patient is a 65-year-old male who presents with shortness of breath and chest pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac exam reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. ECG is normal. Diagnosis of possible COPD exacerbation or cardiac ischemia is being considered. Patient is admitted for further evaluation.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of shortness of breath and chest pain. Diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and ischemic heart disease (IHD) is made based on medical history, physical exam, and diagnostic testing. Treatment includes bronchodilators and oxygen therapy for COPD, and medication for IHD.
transcription:
Date: 01/15/2019

Patient: John Doe

Reason for Visit: Shortness of breath and chest pain

History of Present Illness:
Patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and chest pain for the past two weeks. Symptoms are worse with exertion and at rest. Patient denies any fever, chills, or cough.

Past Medical History:
Patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus, all well controlled with medications.
Patient also has a history of myocardial infarction in 2012 and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in 2013.
Patient smoked one pack per day for 30 years and quit 10 years ago.

Medications:
Lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, metformin, and aspirin.

Allergies:
Patient is allergic to penicillin.

Physical Exam:
Vital signs: BP 140/85, HR 85, RR 20, O2 sat 98% on room air.
Cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 and S2 normal.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation and percussion.
Abdomen: Soft and non-tender.
Extremities: Pulses are 2+ in all extremities.

Diagnostic Tests:
Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
ECG shows sinus rhythm with T wave inversions in leads V3-V6, consistent with ischemic heart disease (IHD).
Lab results: Hgb 13.5, WBC 7.5, Plt 250, BUN 22, Cr 1.2, Na 138, K 3.9, Cl 101, CO2 24, Glu 115, and Ca 9.5.

Diagnosis:
Patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and ischemic heart disease (IHD).

Treatment:
Patient will be started on bronchodilators and oxygen therapy for COPD.
Patient will be continued on medication for IHD, including aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin.

description: Patient presented with shortness of breath and chest pain. Diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and coronary artery disease. Treatment with bronchodilators and statins.
transcription: Patient presents with symptoms of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient is a 65-year-old male, with a medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient reports smoking a pack a day for 40 years and quit 5 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has a persistent cough, and crackles are heard in the lower lung fields. Pulse oximetry is 94% on room air. A chest x-ray is obtained and shows hyperinflation and signs of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The patient is diagnosed with exacerbation of COPD with congestive heart failure (CHF) secondary to CAD. Treatment includes bronchodilators, inhaled steroids, and oxygen therapy. The patient is discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician for ongoing management of his COPD and CAD.
sample_name: COPD with CHF secondary to CAD

description: Patient presented with chronic left hip pain. Diagnosis: Hip osteoarthritis. Treatment: Total hip replacement surgery scheduled.
transcription: Patient presents with chronic left hip pain. On examination, there is pain with range of motion and crepitus is appreciated. X-rays show joint space narrowing and osteophytes. Diagnosis: hip osteoarthritis. Treatment: total hip replacement surgery scheduled.

description: Consultation for left hip pain. X-rays show osteoarthritis. Patient is a candidate for hip replacement.
transcription: Patient presents for consultation complaining of left hip pain. On physical examination, there is pain with range of motion. X-rays of the hip show joint space narrowing and osteophytes, consistent with osteoarthritis. The patient is a candidate for hip replacement.

description: Patient presented with right hip pain and difficulty ambulating. X-rays showed severe osteoarthritis. Surgical replacement of the hip was performed.
transcription: Patient presents with a complaint of right hip pain and difficulty ambulating. On physical examination, there is pain with range of motion and tenderness over the right hip. X-rays of the hip reveal severe osteoarthritis. The patient is scheduled for surgical replacement of the hip.

description: Patient presented with right hip pain and difficulty weight bearing. Diagnosis of osteoarthritis and right hip replacement recommended.
transcription: Patient presents with right hip pain and difficulty weight bearing. On exam, there is pain with range of motion and tenderness over the right hip. X-rays show joint space narrowing and osteophytes. Diagnosis of osteoarthritis is made. Recommendation for right hip replacement is made.

description: Patient presented with left hip pain and difficulty ambulating. Diagnostic imaging revealed femoral neck fracture. Surgical intervention with total hip arthroplasty was performed.
transcription:
Date: 12/14/2021

Patient presents to the emergency department with left hip pain and difficulty ambulating.
Past medical history: hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia.
Allergies: penicillin.
Vital signs: BP 138/78, HR 86, RR 18, T 36.9C.
Exam: left hip has tenderness to palpation.
Labs: CBC, BMP, UA.
Imaging: left hip X-ray shows a fracture of the femoral neck.
Diagnosis: left femoral neck fracture.
Treatment: surgery scheduled for 12/17/2021 for total hip arthroplasty.

description: Patient presents with pain and limited range of motion in left knee. Diagnosis of patellafemoral syndrome. Non-surgical treatment initiated.
transcription: Patient presents to the clinic today complaining of pain and limited range of motion in his left knee. The patient denies any trauma to the area. On exam, there is tenderness to palpation over the patella, crepitus with extension, and pain with squatting and stair climbing. X-rays were obtained and show a normal patella and femoral alignment. Diagnosis of patellafemoral syndrome is made, and non-surgical treatment has been initiated.

description: Patient presents with left hip pain. X-rays reveal degenerative joint disease. Consultation with orthopedic surgeon recommended for further evaluation and management.
transcription: Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of left hip pain of 2 weeks duration. The patient is a 65 year old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus type 2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals pain with deep gluteal squeeze and left hip range of motion, but no deformity or shortening. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and urinalysis, are unremarkable. X-rays of the pelvis and left hip are obtained, revealing degenerative joint disease with no fracture or dislocation. The patient is referred to orthopedic surgery for further evaluation and management.

description: Patient presents with left hip pain and limited range of motion. Diagnosis is osteoarthritis. Treatment includes pain management and physical therapy.
transcription: Patient presents with left hip pain and limited range of motion. On examination, there is tenderness over the left hip joint and crepitus is appreciated during motion. X-rays demonstrate joint space narrowing and osteophytes. Diagnosis is osteoarthritis. Treatment includes pain management with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and acetaminophen, as well as physical therapy to improve range of motion and strength.

description: Procedure for a patient with a fractured right wrist. X-ray confirmed. Cast applied and scheduled for follow-up in 2 weeks.
transcription: Patient presents with a fracture in the right wrist. X-ray confirms the diagnosis. A cast is applied, and the patient is scheduled for follow-up in two weeks.

description: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealing a 4cm mass in the sigmoid colon with features suggestive of malignancy.
transcription:
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed on (date) in (patient) for evaluation of (indication). Images were obtained with (technique) protocol and reconstructed using (reconstruction algorithm). The study was reviewed by (radiologist) with the following findings:

The study demonstrates a well-defined, low attenuation mass in the sigmoid colon measuring 4 cm in greatest dimension (arrow). The mass is heterogeneous and enhances with contrast. There is associated sigmoid colonic wall thickening. The features are highly suggestive of a malignant process. The remainder of the abdomen and pelvis is unremarkable.

description: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis performed on a 52-year-old female patient for follow-up of a previous mass in the liver. No significant findings.
transcription: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis performed on a 52-year-old female patient for follow-up of a previous mass in the liver. No significant findings.
sample_name: CT Scan of Abdomen and Pelvis

description: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis for evaluation of suspected colorectal cancer. Findings are consistent with a 3.5 cm mass in the sigmoid colon.
transcription: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed for evaluation of suspected colorectal cancer. The study was unenhanced. The images were reviewed for bone metastases. No findings to suggest metastatic disease were identified. The small bowel and colon were well distended. The stomach was not well distended and was not fully examined. The duodenal and jejunal loops were not well distended. The gallbladder was not visualized. The common bile duct was not visualized. The liver was 11 cm in craniocaudal dimension. The hepatic parenchyma was mildly steatotic. The spleen was 12 cm in craniocaudal dimension. The pancreas was normal in size and appearance. The adrenal glands were normal in size and appearance. There is a 3.5 cm mass in the sigmoid colon in the region of the splenic flexure. The mass is hypodense to the adjacent colon and does not enhance with intravenous contrast. The mass does not invade the adjacent splenic capsule. The distal colon and rectum were otherwise unremarkable. No evidence of lymphadenopathy was identified. The soft tissue windows were reviewed for the presence of lymphoma. No findings to suggest lymphoma were identified.

description: A radiological examination of the abdomen and pelvis using computed tomography (CT) imaging. The patient is asked to hold their breath while the CT machine takes multiple images of the area. Contrast dye may be administered to enhance the visibility of certain structures.
transcription: Abdomen and Pelvis CT, contrast

description: MRI scan results for patient with suspected brain tumor. No obvious abnormalities found.
transcription: MRI scan performed on 08/25/2021 for patient J.D. (62 years old) with suspected brain tumor. Images obtained using a 3 Tesla MRI machine. No obvious abnormalities found on initial review by radiologist.

description: CT scan results of patient with suspected lung cancer
transcription: Patient is a 62 year old male with history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 50 pack year smoking history who presented with cough and shortness of breath. Chest CT scan was performed for further evaluation of suspected lung cancer. CT findings are consistent with a 3.5 cm part solid part cystic mass in the right upper lobe most likely representing a part solid part cystic bronchiectasis versus part solid part cystic adenocarcinoma. No evidence of lymphadenopathy or pleural effusion.
sample_name: Chest CT for suspected lung cancer

description: CT scan of the chest with contrast for suspected pulmonary embolus.
transcription: CT scan of the chest with contrast for suspected pulmonary embolus. The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus. The scan reveals a large clot in the right pulmonary artery extending into the right upper lobe pulmonary artery. There is also a smaller clot in the left lower lobe pulmonary artery. The main stem bronchi and lung parenchyma are clear.
sample_name: CT Chest with Contrast for Pulmonary Embolus

description: Radiology report for a patient with a history of breast cancer. Mammogram reveals a spiculated mass in the left breast. Biopsy confirms malignancy. Recommendations for further imaging and treatment discussed.
transcription: REPORT FOR: JANE DOE DOB: 07/22/1965. IMAGE DATE: 05/25/2018. TECHNICIAN: JANE DOE. READING PERFORMED BY: DR. JOHNSON. INTERPRETATION: This is a mammographic examination of the left breast performed for evaluation of a palpable mass. Findings: In the upper outer quadrant, there is a spiculated mass measuring 2.5 cm x 2.2 cm. The mass is circumscribed and distorts adjacent tissue. There is associated skin thickening. The mass is highly suspicious for malignancy. The remainder of the left breast and axilla appear normal. RECOMMENDATION: Further imaging and biopsy are recommended. Re-call in 6 months for surveillance. BIOPSY: The patient underwent a left breast core needle biopsy on 06/04/2018. Histopathology confirmed invasive ductal carcinoma.

description: This medical record includes a CT scan of the patient's abdomen and pelvis, as well as an X-ray of the patient's left leg. The CT scan reveals a mass in the patient's liver and an enlarged spleen. The X-ray shows no abnormalities.
transcription: CT scan of abdomen and pelvis performed today reveals a 5 cm heterogenous mass lesion in segment 5 of the liver, with surrounding infiltration and compression of the portal vein and hepatic vein. The spleen is markedly enlarged, measuring 17 cm in craniocaudal dimension. The remainder of the abdomen and pelvis appear unremarkable. CT-guided biopsy of the liver mass was performed.

description: CT scan of the abdomen performed on a 42-year-old female patient. No significant findings.
transcription: CT scan of the abdomen performed on a 42-year-old female patient. No significant findings.

description: Radiographic examination of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast for evaluation of the urinary tract.
transcription: 40 YEAR OLD F EMALE. REQUEST: RADIOGRAPHIC EXAMINATION OF THE ABDOMEN AND PELVIS WITH CONTRAST FOR EVALUATION OF THE URINARY TRACT. TECHNIQUE: LATERAL AND ANTEROPOSTERIOR KIDNEY, URETEROGRAMS AND BLADDER. TECHNIQUE: LATERAL AND ANTEROPOSTERIOR KIDNEY, URETEROGRAMS AND BLADDER. FINDINGS: THE KIDNEYS AND URETERS ARE NORMALLY CONFIGURED. THE BLADDER IS FULL AND NORMALLY CONFIGURED. NO FREE PERIODIC INTRAVESICAL FLUID IS SEEN.
sample_name: Abdomen and Pelvis CT with Contrast

description: A report on a chest X-ray examination
transcription: Chest X-ray examination performed on 03/13/2019 by Dr. Smith. No abnormalities noted. Findings are within normal limits.

description: A radiology report discussing the results of a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis in a 63-year-old male patient.
transcription: CT abdomen and pelvis performed in a 63 year old male with a history of carcinoma of the prostate. No acute pathology identified. There is a large heterogeneously enhancing mass in the left adnexa. There is also a 1.8 cm cystic mass in the right adnexa. There is a 1.2 cm cystic lesion in segment 2 of the liver. The spleen, pancreas and kidneys are within normal limits.

description: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast reveals a 4.5 cm mass in the left hepatic lobe with a central scar and peripheral enhancement. Multiple small metastases are noted in the liver, lung, and lymph nodes.
transcription: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast was performed in this 56 year-old female with a history of colon cancer. The liver shows a 4.5 cm mass in the left hepatic lobe with a central scar and peripheral enhancement. Multiple small metastases are noted in both the liver and the lungs as well as in the lymph nodes. No acute or chronic cholecystitis is identified.
sample_name: Abdomen and Pelvis CT with Contrast

description: Consultation for hypertension, hyperlipidemia and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Prescribes medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and refers patient for endoscopy to evaluate for Barrett's esophagus.
transcription: Patient presents for follow up. BP 150/95, pulse 77, BMI 27. On medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Review of systems is positive for heartburn and regurgitation. Abdomen is benign. Recommends continuing current meds for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Recommends endoscopy to evaluate for Barrett's esophagus.

description: Consultation for recurrent chest pain in a 67-year-old male. Patient denies any cardiac risk factors. ECG shows sinus rhythm with no significant abnormalities. Diagnosis of non-cardiac chest pain. Recommendation for follow-up with primary care physician.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up for recurrent chest pain. Onset is sudden and sharp in nature, radiating to the left shoulder and arm. Duration is approximately 30 minutes. Patient denies any associated symptoms such as shortness of breath, palpitations, or diaphoresis. Medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both well controlled on medication. Family history is negative for cardiovascular disease. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows sinus rhythm with a rate of 85 beats per minute and no significant ST-T wave changes or arrhythmias. Labs are within normal limits. Diagnosis is non-cardiac chest pain. Patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and management.

description: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of episodic dizziness and vertigo. The symptoms are triggered by sudden head movements and last for several seconds to a minute. The patient denies any associated symptoms such as hearing loss, tinnitus, or nausea. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications include losartan, atorvastatin, and finasteride. Exam is unremarkable aside from mild bilateral pseudotumor cerebri. Diagnosis is likely benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. Management includes vestibular rehabilitation therapy and avoiding sudden head movements.
transcription: Patient is a 65-year-old male presenting to the clinic with complaints of episodic dizziness and vertigo triggered by sudden head movements and lasting several seconds to a minute. Denies associated symptoms such as hearing loss, tinnitus, or nausea. PMH significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Meds include losartan, atorvastatin, and finasteride. Exam unremarkable except for mild bilateral pseudotumor cerebri. Diagnosis likely benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. Management includes vestibular rehabilitation therapy and avoiding sudden head movements.
sample_name: General Medicine Consultation: Dizziness and Vertigo

description: Consultation for a 62 year old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation, presenting with a 2 week history of shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain and a dry cough. Examiner notes right sided crackles, pedal edema and a pulsatile liver. Chest x-ray shows right lower lobe infiltrate. Diagnosis: Community acquired pneumonia.
transcription: 62 year old male presents with a 2 week history of shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain and a dry cough. PMH: hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation. Exam: right sided crackles, pedal edema, pulsatile liver. CXR: right lower lobe infiltrate. Dx: community acquired pneumonia.
sample_name: Consultation for a 62 year old male

description: Patient presented with symptoms of fatigue and shortness of breath. Diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension. Prescribed bronchodilators and inhaled steroids. Follow-up appointment scheduled in 6 months.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. The patient is a 65-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) diagnosed in 2012. The patient reports that his symptoms of COPD have been worsening over the past few months, with increased shortness of breath on exertion and a persistent productive cough. The patient denies any fever, chills, or chest pain. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile, and vital signs are stable. Examination of the chest reveals mild expiratory wheezing. A chest X-ray is obtained and reveals hyperinflation and chronic changes consistent with COPD. The patient is started on inhaled bronchodilators and inhaled steroids. Follow-up appointment is scheduled for 6 months.

description: Consultation for a 55 year old female patient with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presenting with symptoms of fatigue and generalized weakness. Laboratory tests show anemia and thyroid function tests are pending. Patient is advised to follow up in two weeks for repeat laboratory tests.
transcription: 55 year old female patient presented for routine follow up. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patient reports feeling fatigued and weak. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL, hematocrit of 32.0%, and mean corpuscular volume of 80.2 fL (reference range: 81-97 fL). Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (FT4) levels are pending. Patient is advised to follow up in two weeks for repeat laboratory tests.

description: Consultation for a 68 year old female with a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia presenting with symptoms of fatigue and shortness of breath. Patient was diagnosed with congestive heart failure and treated with furosemide and a loop diuretic.
transcription: 68 year old female presenting to her primary care physician for follow up. Patient reports symptoms of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. On exam patient is afebrile, pulse is 92, and BP is 145/85. Cardiac exam reveals S3 and lower extremity edema. Echocardiogram reveals an ejection fraction of 35%. Diagnosis of congestive heart failure is made and patient is started on furosemide and a loop diuretic.

description: Consultation for a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease presenting with worsening dyspnea on exertion for two weeks. Patient reports cough and sputum production. Physical exam reveals bilateral lower lung crackles. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Patient is diagnosed with pneumonia and started on antibiotics.
transcription: 65 year old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion for two weeks. The patient also reports cough and sputum production. On physical exam, there are bilateral lower lung crackles. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, consistent with pneumonia. The patient is started on antibiotics for treatment.
sample_name: Consultation for Pneumonia in a Male with Chronic Medical Conditions

description: Consultation for hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes. Prescription for metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin.
transcription: Patient presents with a history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes mellitus type 2. Blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Fasting plasma glucose is 126 mg/dL. Labs show an HbA1c of 7.2%. ECG is normal. Patient is started on metformin 500 mg BID, lisinopril 10 mg QD, and simvastatin 20 mg QD. Patient will return in 3 months for follow-up.

description: Consultation with a general physician for general health check-up. Patient reports symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and joint pain. Blood tests and physical examination are ordered. Prescription for diet and exercise is provided.
transcription: Patient presents for routine health check-up. Complains of fatigue, weight gain, and joint pain. Vital signs within normal limits. Abdomen benign. No lumps or masses palpated. Neurologic and cardiovascular examination unremarkable. Labs show slightly elevated liver enzymes. Prescribes diet and exercise.

description: Record of a routine endoscopy procedure for a patient with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Biopsies are taken and show signs of chronic inflammation. Diagnosis of gastritis and esophagitis is confirmed. Treatment plan includes medication and lifestyle modifications.
transcription: Patient presented for routine endoscopy due to symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) was performed with the following findings: Esophagus: Mild erythema in the distal esophagus, no stricture or ulceration. Gastric body: Mild erythema, no ulceration or erosion. Gastric antrum: Mild erythema, no erosion or ulceration. Duodenum: Normal. Biopsies were taken from the esophagus and stomach. Histopathology revealed chronic inflammation in the esophagus and stomach, consistent with esophagitis and gastritis, respectively. Treatment plan includes proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and lifestyle modifications, such as avoidance of acidic foods and tobacco cessation.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of abdominal pain and bloating. Upper endoscopy revealed erosive esophagitis and gastritis. Biopsies were taken for further evaluation.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of epigastric pain and bloating. Onset was 2 weeks ago. No significant past medical history. No allergies. Medications include ibuprofen and omeprazole. Physical exam is unremarkable. Labs are within normal limits. Abdominal x-ray is negative for obstruction or free air. Upper endoscopy is scheduled. At the time of the procedure, the patient is in no acute distress. The esophagus is inspected, revealing erosive esophagitis. The stomach is visualized, revealing erosive gastritis. Biopsies are taken from both the esophagus and stomach for further evaluation.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. Diagnostic tests reveal inflammation of the colon and small intestine. Treatment includes medication and dietary changes.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up for symptoms of abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea that have been present for the past several weeks. The patient reports that the symptoms have been worsening over time. The patient denies any other symptoms, including fevers, chills, or weight loss. The patient reports no known food allergies. The patient reports a diet that is high in fiber and includes wheat and dairy products. The patient reports that he has tried over-the-counter medications for his symptoms with no relief. The patient reports that his wife also has symptoms of bloating and diarrhea. On examination, the patient appears well-appearing and is in no acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal exam is notable for mild diffuse tenderness without rebound or guarding. Rectal exam is deferred. Initial labs are within normal limits, including a CBC, metabolic panel, and thyroid function tests. Urinalysis and urine culture are pending. Stool studies are ordered, including a fecal leukocyte test, fecal fat test, and fecal elastase. Colonoscopy is scheduled for 6 weeks from now. In the interim, the patient is prescribed mesalamine 4000mg daily in divided doses, to be taken with food, and a low FODMAP diet, with the goal of reducing fiber intake and minimizing intake of wheat and dairy products.

description: A patient presents with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and undergoes an upper endoscopy with biopsies. Pathology reveals Helicobacter pylori infection and gastritis.
transcription: Patient presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of heartburn and acid regurgitation. His symptoms are worse after meals and when lying down. He denies dysphagia or weight loss. On physical exam, he has no significant findings. His labs are unremarkable. Upper endoscopy is performed, revealing mild esophagitis and grade 1 esophageal reflux. Biopsies are taken and reveal Helicobacter pylori infection and active chronic gastritis.

description: Case presentation: A 52-year-old male presented with abdominal pain and weight loss. Endoscopic findings revealed a mass in the distal esophagus. Histopathology confirmed a diagnosis of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Treatment consisted of chemoradiation therapy. Follow-up endoscopy showed a complete response. Keywords: esophageal cancer, adenocarcinoma, chemoradiation therapy, complete response.
transcription: 52-year-old male presented with a chief complaint of abdominal pain and a 15 pound weight loss over a 4 month period. On exam, he was found to have mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. Abdominal ultrasound and CT scan revealed no acute pathology. Endoscopy showed a 3 cm mass in the distal esophagus with narrowing, which biopsy revealed to be an adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent chemoradiation therapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel, followed by concurrent radiation therapy. Follow-up endoscopy 12 months after treatment showed complete resolution of the tumor mass, with no evidence of recurrence.

description: A detailed account of a patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and diagnostic procedures, including endoscopy, biopsy, and imaging studies. The transcription also touches on the patient's medical history and treatment plan.
transcription: Patient presents with a 6-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. Symptoms are not associated with food intake and are not relieved by bowel movements. Patient denies weight loss, fever, or melena. PMH includes hypertension and gout, managed with allopurinol. Meds include lisinopril, aspirin, and simvastatin. On exam, patient appears comfortable, BP 138/82, HR 78, RR 16, and T 37. Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. Bowel sounds are present. Rectal exam reveals no masses or hemorrhoids. Labs are pending. Endoscopy is scheduled for tomorrow morning. Patient is instructed to discontinue aspirin and simvastatin tonight.

description: Patient presents with seizures and memory loss. Brain MRI shows multiple lesions consistent with ischemic events. Diagnosis: Cerebrovascular disease.
transcription: Patient is a 65-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with a one-week history of recurrent seizures. His symptoms began with a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure, followed by a focal right-sided seizure. Since then, he has had several brief episodes of loss of awareness. He denies any head trauma, syncope, or other neurologic symptoms. He is taking lisinopril, atorvastatin, and simvastatin. Physical examination is unremarkable. Neurological examination reveals mild memory impairment. Laboratory studies are unremarkable. Brain MRI shows multiple areas of signal abnormality in the left temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, consistent with ischemic events. The patient's symptoms and imaging are most consistent with cerebrovascular disease.

description: The patient is a 58-year-old male presenting with a history of headaches and dizziness. Neurological examination reveals cranial nerve deficits and signs of cerebellar dysfunction. Brain MRI shows multiple enhancing lesions. Lumbar puncture reveals elevated protein and oligoclonal bands. Diagnosis: Multiple Sclerosis.
transcription: Patient is a 58-year-old male presenting with a chief complaint of recurrent headaches and dizziness. The headaches are described as dull, bilateral, and occasionally associated with mild photophobia. The dizziness is described as a feeling of lightheadedness and disequilibrium, which is worse with positional changes. The symptoms have been occurring for several months and are worsening in frequency and duration. The patient denies any associated symptoms, such as visual disturbances, weakness, or numbness. On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. Cranial nerve examination reveals a left-sided horizontal gaze palsy and a left-sided superior oblique palsy. The remainder of the cranial nerve examination is normal. The patient demonstrates signs of cerebellar dysfunction, including dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesis, and rebound phenomenon. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. The remainder of the neurological examination is normal. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals multiple enhancing lesions, predominantly in the periventricular and juxtacortical regions, as well as in the left cerebellar hemisphere. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals an elevated protein of 90 mg/dL and the presence of oligoclonal bands. The patient is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. The patient is advised to follow up with neurology for further evaluation and management.

description: Patient presented with recurrent seizures and history of epilepsy. EEG showed epileptiform activity in temporal regions. Diagnosis: Temporal lobe epilepsy.
transcription: Patient is a 35-year-old male presenting with recurrent seizures. He has a history of epilepsy with a previous diagnosis of temporal lobe epilepsy. The patient's seizures have been poorly controlled on medication. The patient reports aura followed by loss of consciousness and post-ictal confusion. The patient denies any focal neurologic symptoms between seizures. The patient reports a seizure two weeks ago and another seizure two days ago. The patient reports no other medical history of note. Family history is noncontributory. The patient denies any medication allergies. The patient's medications include levetiracetam and lamotrigine. The patient is right-handed. Physical exam is normal. Neurologic exam is normal. Cognitive function is normal. EEG shows epileptiform activity in the temporal regions. CT head is normal. MRI brain shows left temporal atrophy. Diagnosis is temporal lobe epilepsy. Recommendation is continuation of current medications.
sample_name: Recurrent Seizures in a Patient with Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

description: Patient presented with symptoms of vertigo and dizziness. Neurological examination revealed nystagmus and ataxia. Diagnosis of vestibular neuritis was made and treatment with steroids was initiated.
transcription: Patient presented to the emergency department complaining of vertigo and dizziness. The patient reported that the symptoms began suddenly and have been persistent for the past three days. The patient also reported some hearing loss in the affected ear. On physical examination, the patient exhibited nystagmus and ataxia. Neurological examination was otherwise unremarkable. Based on the patient's symptoms and findings on examination, a diagnosis of vestibular neuritis was made. The patient was started on steroids to help alleviate symptoms.

description: Patient presents with a history of migraines and cognitive decline. Examination reveals focal neurological deficits. MRI reveals a lesion in the left temporal lobe. Diagnosis: Left temporal lobe glioma.
transcription: Patient is a 52-year-old male presenting with a 5-year history of migraines. He reports that his migraines are becoming more frequent and are now associated with cognitive decline. He reports forgetfulness, difficulty with language, and difficulty with calculation. His neurological examination reveals left-sided weakness in the face and arm, as well as aphasia. MRI reveals a 2.5 cm lesion in the left temporal lobe, consistent with a glioma.
sample_name: Neurological Evaluation of Patient with Migraines and Cognitive Decline

description: Consultation for a 44-year-old female with a history of migraine headaches. Complains of intermittent left-sided weakness and numbness for the past week. Exam reveals left facial droop and weakness of left arm and leg. MRI shows a lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere. Diagnosis: Cerebellar stroke.
transcription: 44-year-old female presents for a neurology consultation regarding intermittent left-sided weakness and numbness that have been present for the past week. She has a history of migraine headaches. Her exam reveals left facial droop and weakness of the left arm and leg. MRI shows a lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere, which is diagnostic of a cerebellar stroke.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of seizures. CT scan showed no abnormalities. Patient was diagnosed with epilepsy and prescribed anticonvulsant medication.
transcription: Patient is a 35-year-old male presenting with recurrent episodes of loss of consciousness and jerking of the extremities. The patient reports that these episodes began approximately 2 months ago, and occur daily. The patient reports that the episodes last for approximately 1-2 minutes, and that he is unaware of his surroundings during these episodes. The patient denies any head trauma, and reports no other symptoms. The patient is otherwise healthy, and takes no medications on a regular basis. Physical examination is unremarkable. CT scan of the head is negative for acute pathology. The patient is diagnosed with epilepsy, and is prescribed phenytoin 100mg PO BID.

description: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented with a one-month history of progressive memory loss, confusion, and gait disturbance. Neurological examination revealed a global aphasia, left gaze preference, left hemiparesis, and hyperreflexia in all four limbs. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a large mass in the left temporal lobe with surrounding edema. The patient underwent left temporal lobectomy, and histopathology confirmed a grade IV astrocytoma.
transcription: 65 year old male presented with a one month history of progressive memory loss, confusion and gait disturbance. Past medical history was significant for hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. Neurological examination revealed global aphasia, left gaze preference, left hemiparesis and hyperreflexia in all four limbs. MRI showed a large mass in the left temporal lobe with surrounding oedema. Patient underwent left temporal lobectomy. Histopathology confirmed grade IV astrocytoma.
sample_name: Left temporal lobectomy for astrocytoma in a 65-year-old male

description: Pregnancy and delivery of a healthy baby via cesarean section.
transcription: Patient presents at 39 weeks and 2 days gestation for scheduled cesarean delivery. Cervix is 1-2 cm dilated, fetal station is -2, fetal heart tones are in the 140's bpm, and the uterus is contracting every 2-3 minutes. Patient received antibiotics prior to incision. A healthy female infant is delivered via cesarean section. Weight is 7 lbs 14 oz. Apgar scores are 9, 9, and 9 at 1, 5, and 10 minutes respectively. Mother and baby are doing well.

description: Prenatal visit at 36 weeks for patient with history of gestational diabetes. Discussion of diet, glucose monitoring, and delivery plan. Vaginal delivery scheduled for 39 weeks.
transcription: 36 week prenatal visit with (patient). Review of history including gestational diabetes mellitus. Discussion of diet, glucose monitoring, and delivery plan. Vaginal delivery scheduled for 39 weeks.

description: A 32-year-old woman with a history of infertility presents for routine prenatal care at 8 weeks gestation. She reports a positive pregnancy test and a menstrual cycle of 35 days. Ultrasound confirms a viable intrauterine pregnancy. Patient is advised to return for follow-up in 4 weeks.
transcription: 32 year old female presents for routine prenatal care at 8 weeks gestation. Patient reports a positive pregnancy test and a menstrual cycle of 35 days. Ultrasound confirms a viable intrauterine pregnancy. Patient is advised to return for follow-up in 4 weeks.

description: Procedure for removal of bladder stone using lithotripsy
transcription: Patient presented with symptoms of urinary retention. Urinalysis showed hematuria. CT scan revealed a large bladder stone. Cystoscopy confirmed the presence of a bladder stone. Patient underwent lithotripsy for the removal of the stone. Procedure was uneventful. Patient was discharged the following day.

description: Procedure for removal of bladder tumor using transurethral resection of bladder (TURBT) and fulguration. Diagnosis of bladder cancer. Discussion of follow-up options.
transcription: Procedure: 27-year-old male with history of bladder cancer presents for transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) due to recurrent bladder tumor. Anesthesia: General. Diagnosis: Bladder cancer. Procedure: TURBT with fulguration of lesion in the left lateral wall. Estimated Blood Loss: 50 cc. Specimens were submitted and pathology was positive for urothelial carcinoma. Follow-up options discussed, including cystoscopy in 3 months and possible intravesical therapy.

description: Consultation for 34 year old male with a left flank mass and left ureteral colic. Patient underwent left ureteroscopy and successful extraction of a 3cm x 2cm stone. Patient was discharged on Foley catheter and pain medication.
transcription: 34 year old male presenting with a left flank mass and left ureteral colic. On examination, the patient was found to have a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant. The patient underwent left ureteroscopy for management of a 3cm x 2cm stone. The stone was successfully extracted during the procedure. The patient was discharged with a Foley catheter in place and pain medication.

description: Prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment discussion.
transcription: Dr. Smith is discussing a 65-year-old male patient with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia who presented with lower urinary tract symptoms. After a digital rectal exam and PSA test, a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy was performed, revealing a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient is now undergoing active surveillance and will be scheduled for regular follow-up appointments.
sample_name: Prostate Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment Discussion

description: Procedure for treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in a 67-year-old male patient. Discussion of symptoms, pre-operative evaluation, surgical technique, and post-operative care. Includes reference to transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) and potential complications.
transcription: Case: 67-year-old male with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presenting with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) including frequency, urgency, and hesitancy. Pre-operative evaluation included digital rectal exam (DRE), prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level, and urinalysis (UA). DRE revealed a large, firm prostate with a palpable median lobe. PSA level was within normal limits. UA showed no evidence of infection. The patient was scheduled for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) with monopolar electrocautery. The procedure began with the placement of a Foley catheter and the administration of prophylactic antibiotics. The patient was placed in the lithotomy position and sterile prep was performed. A 22-Fr. Foley catheter was inserted and 200 mL of urine was drained. The catheter was removed and the prostate gland was visualized using a 20-Fr. Cystoscope. The median lobe was dissected and removed using monopolar electrocautery. The remaining adenoma was resected in a piecemeal fashion. The specimen weighed 45 g. Hemostasis was achieved using bipolar cautery and the bladder neck was reconstructed. The Foley catheter was replaced and the patient was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition. Post-operative care included strict intake of fluids, monitoring of urine output, and pain management. The patient was discharged on post-operative day 2 with a Foley catheter in place and scheduled for catheter removal in 1 week.
sample_name: Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) for Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)

description: Prostate cancer treatment discussion.
transcription: Patient presents with PSA 6.6, Gleason 3+3=6, MRI suspicious for extracapsular extension. Discussion of treatment options including active surveillance, radiation therapy, and prostatectomy. Decision for active surveillance with PSA screen every 6 months and repeat MRI in 12 months.

description: Consultation for urinary retention and urgency. Prostate biopsy. Cystoscopy and urethral catheterization. Diagnosis: Prostatic hyperplasia and prostatitis.
transcription: Patient presents with symptoms of urinary retention and urgency. Prostate biopsy is performed. Cystoscopy and urethral catheterization are also performed. Diagnosis includes prostatic hyperplasia and prostatitis.

description: Consultation for a 51-year-old male with a history of bladder cancer and a right ureteral stent for obstructive uropathy. The patient presents with acute urinary retention. Physical exam reveals a palpable bladder. Urine analysis shows bacteriuria. Cystometry reveals a large capacity bladder and an elevated post-void residual volume. The patient is advised to undergo transurethral resection of the bladder neck (TURBN).
transcription: 51-year-old male presenting for follow-up after a right ureteral stent placement for obstructive uropathy secondary to bladder cancer. He now presents with acute urinary retention. His exam is notable for a palpable bladder. Urine analysis shows bacteriuria. Cystometry demonstrates a large capacity bladder and an elevated post-void residual volume. The patient will undergo a transurethral resection of the bladder neck.
sample_name: Consultation for Urinary Retention in a Male with a History of Bladder Cancer and Ureteral Stent
keywords: transurethral resection of the bladder neck (TURBN)

description: Procedure for removal of stone from bladder using lithotripsy and cystoscopy.
transcription: 02/07/2019 14:23: Procedure for removal of stone from bladder using lithotripsy and cystoscopy. Prepped and consented for cystoscopy with lithotripsy for bladder stone. Patient had a Foley catheter placed on 02/06/2019. In the operating room, the catheter was irrigated and 50 cc of blood was drained. The catheter was removed and the bladder was drained of 250 cc of old blood. Cystoscopy showed a 2 cm stone in the bladder neck. Lithotripsy was performed with a holmium laser. The stone was broken into multiple pieces. The fragments were removed with a basket. The bladder was irrigated and inspected. The catheter was replaced and secured. The procedure was uneventful. The catheter will be left for 2 weeks.
sample_name: Procedure for removal of stone from bladder using lithotripsy and cystoscopy.

description: Summary of patient's discharge from the hospital
transcription: Patient was admitted on 01/01/2021 with chief complaint of chest pain. Diagnosis was made of myocardial infarction. Patient underwent emergency angioplasty and stenting. Patient has been managed with medications for heart failure and cardiac arrhythmia. Patient is stable and ready for discharge. Instructions for follow-up care have been provided.

description: Summary of patient's hospital stay and discharge information
transcription: Patient was admitted on 05/01/2021 for management of sepsis secondary to right lower extremity cellulitis. The patient underwent debridement of the right lower extremity on 05/03/2021 and received intravenous antibiotics. The patient improved clinically and was discharged on 05/07/2021. Discharge medications include amoxicillin and clindamycin.

description: Patient was admitted for management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. Treatment included antibiotics and bronchodilators. Patient was discharged with instructions to continue home oxygen therapy and follow-up with primary care physician.
transcription: Discharge Summary: Patient was admitted on 01/25/2021 for management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. The patient presented with a fever of 101.1F, productive cough, and shortness of breath. On admission, the patient's oxygen saturation was 86% on room air. The patient was started on antibiotics (ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h) and bronchodilators (albuterol 4mg via nebulizer q4h). The patient's respiratory status improved and they were discharged on 01/28/2021. The patient was instructed to continue home oxygen therapy (2L via nasal cannula) and to follow-up with their primary care physician for ongoing management of their COPD.

description: Patient was admitted on 01/15/2021 with a diagnosis of pneumonia. The patient received antibiotic therapy and was discharged on 01/20/2021 in stable condition.
transcription: Discharge Summary: Patient was admitted on 01/15/2021 with a diagnosis of pneumonia. The patient received antibiotic therapy and was discharged on 01/20/2021 in stable condition.

description: Summary of patient's discharge from the hospital
transcription: Patient was admitted on 05/10/2021 with chief complaints of shortness of breath and fever. Diagnosis of pneumonia and COVID-19 were made. Patient received antibiotics and oxygen therapy. Fever resolved and oxygen requirements decreased. Patient is now ready for discharge in stable condition.

description: Patient was admitted with symptoms of pneumonia. Antibiotics were administered and patient responded well. Discharge on day 5 with instructions to continue antibiotics at home.
transcription: Discharge Summary: Patient was admitted on 01/01/2021 with complaints of shortness of breath, productive cough, and fever. Chest X-ray revealed consolidation in the right lower lung field, consistent with pneumonia. Patient was started on intravenous antibiotics and oxygen therapy. Symptoms improved and fever resolved. Patient was discharged on 01/05/2021 in stable condition on oral antibiotics for 10 days. Instructions for follow-up care and management of underlying conditions were provided.

description: Evaluation and management of patient with left ear discharge and otalgia. Diagnosis of chronic otitis media with perforation and myringitis. Treatment with antibiotic and steroid drops and follow-up in 1 week.
transcription:
Date: 5/26/2021
Time: 1:30 PM

Patient: James Smith
DOB: 8/15/1980

Chief Complaint: Left ear discharge and otalgia for 2 weeks.

History: 62 year old male with past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Allergies: NKDA. Medications: Lisinopril, Simvastatin.

Exam: Ear, Nose, Throat: Left ear: Perforation of the tympanic membrane with mild erythema and discharge. Right ear: Normoacoustic.

Diagnosis: Chronic otitis media with perforation and myringitis left ear.

Treatment: Antibiotic and steroid drops for 2 weeks. Follow-up in 1 week.

description: Consultation for evaluation of hearing loss and dizziness.
transcription: Patient presented to the ENT clinic for evaluation of hearing loss and dizziness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and asthma. Medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and albuterol inhaler as needed. Otoscopic exam showed left ear canal narrowing with cerumen obstructing the view of the tympanic membrane. Right ear canal and tympanic membrane were normal. Tympanogram revealed left conductive hearing loss. Speech and pure tone audiometry confirmed the findings. Vestibular testing showed a mild right peripheral vestibulopathy. Patient was diagnosed with otitis media with effusion and benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. Recommendations were made for ear canal cleaning, decongestants, and vestibular rehabilitation exercises.

description: Consultation for right ear discharge. Removal of ear wax. Prescription for antibiotic and ear drops. Patient to return in 2 weeks for re-evaluation.
transcription: Patient presents for evaluation of right ear discharge. Ear exam shows cerumen in the external auditory canal. Cerumen removed. Right ear culture and sensitivity to be performed. Prescription for Cefdinir 300mg BID for 10 days and Acetic acid and hydrocortisone drops twice daily for 7 days. Patient is to return in 2 weeks for re-evaluation.

description: Consultation for evaluation of recurrent right ear discharge and otitis externa. Discusses history of ear symptoms, examination findings, and treatment plan including antibiotic drops and follow-up appointment.
transcription:
Date: 3/13/2019 
 
 Patient: John Doe
 DOB: 01/01/1950
 Allergies: Penicillin
 
 Reason for Visit: Recurrent right ear discharge and otitis externa
 
 History:
 - Symptoms started 3 weeks ago
 - Right ear discharge
 - Right ear fullness
 - Some right ear pain
 - No fever
 - No hearing loss
 - No vertigo
 
 Past Medical History:
 - Asthma
 
 Medications:
 - Singulair
 
 Social:
 - Smoker
 - Denies alcohol or drug abuse
 
 Family History:
 - Father: Coronary artery disease
 
 Exam:
 - Right ear discharge
 - Right ear fullness
 - Right ear mild erythematous canal
 - Right ear normal tympanic membrane
 - Left ear: Normal
 
 Diagnosis:
 - Chronic otitis externa
 
 Treatment:
 - Right ear: Ciprofloxacin 0.3% drops BID for 14 days
 - Right ear: Acetic acid 2% drops BID for 14 days
 - Follow-up in 2 weeks

description: Consultation for recurrent right ear discharge and right ear pain. Patient is a 74 year old female with history of right ear myringotomy and tympanoplasty. Otoscopic exam reveals moderate cerumen obstructing canal. Ear culture was performed with results pending. Patient is prescribed ear drops.
transcription:
Date: 6/26/2018

Patient presents for follow up complaint of recurrent right ear discharge and right ear pain. She is a 74 year old female. Past medical history is significant for right ear myringotomy and tympanoplasty. On otoscopic exam today, there is moderate cerumen obstructing the canal. An ear culture has been performed, and results are pending.
sample_name: Consultation for Recurrent Right Ear Discharge and Right Ear Pain

description: Consultation for right ear discharge and pain. Examination reveals right tympanic membrane perforation and otorrhea. Treatment includes antibiotics and ear drops.
transcription: Patient presents with right ear discharge and pain. Exam shows right tympanic membrane perforation with otorrhea. Management includes antibiotics and ear drops.

description: Consultation for recurrent chronic sinusitis with left nasal obstruction and left maxillary sinusitis. Endoscopic sinus surgery performed.
transcription: Consultation for recurrent chronic sinusitis with left nasal obstruction and left maxillary sinusitis. Endoscopic sinus surgery performed.

description: Consultation for right ear discharge and pain. Otoscopic exam reveals a perforated right tympanic membrane with moderate otorrhea. Prescribes antibiotic drops for 7 days. Returns in 1 week for re-evaluation.
transcription:
Date: 5/15/2019

Patient: Jane Doe

Reason for Visit: Right ear discharge and pain.

Pertinent Medical History: Asthma.

Medications: Singulair 10mg PO qd.

Allergies: Penicillin.

Examination: The patient appears to be in no acute distress. The ears are examined in the supine position. The left ear is normal. The right ear has a perforation in the tympanic membrane with moderate otorrhea. Tympanometry is deferred.

Diagnosis: Right ear discharge and pain. Perforated tympanic membrane with otorrhea.

Treatment: Antibiotic ear drops to be instilled 3 times a day for 7 days. The patient is to return in 1 week for re-evaluation.

Plan: Return in 1 week for re-evaluation.

Notes:

description: Consultation for recurrent right ear discharge and pain.
transcription: Patient presents with recurrent right ear discharge and pain. Otoscopic examination reveals a perforation of the right tympanic membrane with discharge. Cultures are pending. Treatment includes ear drops and oral antibiotics.
sample_name: Recurrent Right Ear Discharge and Pain Consultation

description: Consultation for right ear discomfort and tinnitus. Exam shows mild cerumen impaction. Ear lavage and cerumenectomy performed.
transcription: Consultation with Dr. Smith for right ear discomfort and tinnitus. Patient reports some hearing loss in right ear. Otoscopic exam shows some cerumen in the right ear canal. Right ear ENT lavage with 30 ml of sterile saline completed. Cerumen removed in entirety. Exam reveals mild cerumen impaction. Ear lavage with 30 ml of sterile saline completed. Cerumen removed in entirety. Ear exam shows improved view of the tympanic membrane and canal. Ear exam reveals mild cerumen impaction.

description: Consultation for evaluation of recurrent right-sided otitis media and right ear discharge. Discharged on ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone.
transcription:
Date: 1/2/2019

History: 51 year old male with recurrent right ear discharge and right sided otitis media.
Exam: Rt ear: TM intact, EAC open, BG clear, Ohrnea present, BG wax.
Lt ear: TM intact, EAC closed, BG clear.
Labs: None.
Allergies: Penicillin.
Medications: None.
Immunizations: None.
Instructions: Ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone.

description: Consultation for recurrent right ear discharge and right ear pain. Patient underwent myringotomy and tympanoplasty two years ago. Otoscopic exam reveals intact right tympanic membrane. Right ear culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Prescription for antibiotic drops.
transcription:
Date: 3/31/2014 2:24 PM
Name: JOHNSON, JASON

History:
Recurrent right ear discharge and right ear pain.

Exam:
2 years ago: myringotomy and tympanoplasty.
Otoscopic exam reveals intact right tympanic membrane.

Labs:
Right ear culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Assessment:
Recurrent right ear discharge and right ear pain.

Plan:
Antibiotic drops.

description: Procedure performed to remove a meningioma tumor from the left parietal lobe. Patient was discharged on postoperative day 3 with no complications.
transcription: Preop: 62 y/o f presents with headaches and focal seizures. MRI reveals a 3.2 x 2.8 x 3.5 cm meningioma in the left parietal lobe. Neurology consult suggests surgery. Postop: Craniotomy and tumor resection. Pathology: Menigioma. Postop d/c to neurosurgery.

description: Procedure for removal of a subdural hematoma in a 57-year-old male patient using a craniotomy technique. The patient is being monitored for postoperative recovery.
transcription: Procedure for removal of a subdural hematoma in a 57-year-old male patient using a craniotomy technique. The patient was brought to the operating room following a traumatic head injury. A CT scan of the head was performed revealing a right-sided subdural hematoma with midline shift. The patient was taken to the operating room for urgent surgical intervention. In the operating room, the patient was induced with general anesthesia and monitored with standard ASA monitoring. A right parietal craniotomy was performed over the area of the hematoma. The dura was opened and the subdural hematoma was evacuated. The hematoma was found to be 10 ml in size and was removed in its entirety. The wound was irrigated and the dura was closed in a watertight fashion. The bone flap was replaced and secured with titanium plates and screws. The wound was then irrigated and closed in a standard layered fashion. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for postoperative monitoring.
sample_name: Subdural Hematoma Removal in a 57-Year-Old Male
