description: Surgical intervention for a patient with a meningioma tumor in the brain. Craniotomy performed and tumor removed. Post-operative care and monitoring included.
transcription: Case: 36 year old female with a meningioma tumor in the left frontal lobe of the brain. Patient presented with seizures and headaches. Pre-operative imaging studies revealed a 3.5 cm mass lesion in the left frontal lobe. Craniotomy was performed and the tumor was successfully removed. Patient is recovering well post-operatively.

description: A patient with a history of epilepsy undergoes a craniotomy and resection of a left frontal lobe tumor. Postoperative course is uncomplicated.
transcription: Patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of epilepsy, presenting with focal seizures. CT scan of the head shows a 2.5 cm left frontal lobe mass lesion. Patient undergoes left frontal craniotomy and resection of the lesion. Pathology reveals a grade II astrocytoma. Postoperative course is uncomplicated.

description: Surgical procedure to remove a brain tumor in a 58-year-old male patient. Craniotomy performed at left parietal region. Tumor successfully extracted. Post-op recovery uneventful.
transcription: Case: 58-year-old male with brain tumor. Diagnosed with astrocytoma. Scheduled for neurosurgical intervention. Prepped and transferred to operating room. Craniotomy performed at left parietal region. Tumor successfully extracted. Dura closed and secured. Patient transferred to recovery room in stable condition.

description: Procedure for removal of meningioma in a 60-year-old female patient using the craniotomy technique.
transcription: Pre-op: 60-year-old female with meningioma. MRI and CT scans. No neurologic deficits. Hematology and coagulation studies normal. Prepped and draped. Intra-op: Midline incision. Burr hole at right frontal lobe. Craniotomy. Dura opened. Meningioma exposed. Removed using suction and curettes. Closure with bone wax and fibrillar. Post-op: Wound closed with interrupted sutures. Dressing applied. Intravenous antibiotics continued. Patient returned to ward in stable condition.
sample_name: Removal of Meningioma in a 60-year-old Female Patient

description: A 58-year-old male presents with left-sided weakness and gait disturbance following a syncopal episode. The patient undergoes a left frontotemporal craniotomy for removal of an epidermoid tumor.
transcription: 58 year old male presents to the emergency department with left sided weakness and gait disturbance following a syncopal episode. Exam is notable for left facial droop and weakness of the left arm and leg. MRI of the brain shows a left frontal and temporal lobe mass lesion. Patient is taken to the operating room for a left frontotemporal craniotomy. Gross total resection of an epidermoid tumor is achieved. Pathology confirms an epidermoid tumor. Postoperative course is uncomplicated.
sample_name: Epidermoid Tumor of Left Frontotemporal Region

description: Procedure for a 51-year-old female patient with a recurrent meningioma in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The patient is under general anesthesia and is placed in the prone position. The surgical team includes the neurosurgeon, neuroanesthesiologist, and neurology resident. The patient is given mannitol and dexamethasone prior to the surgery. The surgical plan is to remove the meningioma with preservation of brainstem and cerebellar function.
transcription: 51-year-old female patient presented with a recurrent meningioma in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The patient was placed under general anesthesia and was placed in the prone position. The surgical team consisted of the neurosurgeon, neuroanesthesiologist, and neurology resident. Prior to the surgery, the patient received mannitol and dexamethasone. The surgical plan was to remove the meningioma with preservation of brainstem and cerebellar function.

description: Patient presents with bone pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and monoclonal immunoglobulin M (IgM) spike. Bone marrow biopsy confirms diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Treatment with chemotherapy and immunotherapy is initiated.
transcription: Patient: I've been feeling pretty unwell lately. I have this constant bone pain and I'm just so fatigued. I've lost a significant amount of weight too. Doctor: Alright, let's run some tests to figure out what's going on. Your complete blood count (CBC) shows pancytopenia, which means that all your blood cell counts are low. Your lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is also elevated. This can be a sign of a hematologic malignancy. Patient: Hematologic malignancy? That sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it's a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. In your case, we'll need to do a bone marrow biopsy to confirm our suspicions. Once we have that result, we can discuss treatment options with you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The biopsy revealed that you have multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer that affects plasma cells in the bone marrow. We'll need to initiate treatment with chemotherapy and immunotherapy to manage your symptoms and slow the progression of the disease. Patient: What kind of chemotherapy and immunotherapy will I be getting? Doctor: We'll start with a regimen called bortezomib, melphalan, and prednisone. We'll also add the immunotherapy drug daratumumab to your treatment plan. This is a new therapy that has shown promise in patients with multiple myeloma. We'll monitor your response to treatment closely and adjust your care plan as needed.
sample_name: Multiple Myeloma Diagnosis and Treatment Plan

description: Patient with acute myeloid leukemia presenting with fever, fatigue, and pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals 80% blasts with FLT3-ITD mutation. Induction therapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin initiated.
transcription: Patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic myelomonocytic leukemia, diagnosed in 2011, presenting with fever, fatigue, and night sweats for the past 2 weeks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam is significant for pallor and palpable splenomegaly. Labs show a white blood cell count of 3.3 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, and platelets of 67 x 10^9/L. Bone marrow biopsy reveals 80% blasts with FLT3-ITD mutation. Induction therapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin initiated.

description: Patient presents with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with FLT3-ITD mutation. Underwent induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin followed by consolidation with high-dose cytarabine. Currently in complete remission for 8 months. Peripheral blood shows 1% blasts, no Auer rods, and normal myeloid and erythroid lineage. Bone marrow biopsy shows 3% blasts, myeloid hyperplasia, and increased trilineage hematopoiesis. Cytogenetic study of bone marrow shows 5q- and complex abnormalities. Molecular studies show persistence of FLT3-ITD mutation. Diagnosis: Post-remission AML with 5q- and complex abnormalities. Recommendations: Further therapy not recommended at this time. Close follow-up recommended.
transcription: Patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with FLT3-ITD mutation. He underwent induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin followed by consolidation with high-dose cytarabine. He has been in complete remission for 8 months. His current complete blood count is significant for a white blood cell count of 4.2 x 10^9/L with 1% blasts, hemoglobin of 11.8 g/dL, and platelets of 139 x 10^9/L. There are no Auer rods seen. His bone marrow biopsy shows 3% blasts, myeloid hyperplasia, and increased trilineage hematopoiesis. The cytogenetic study of the bone marrow shows a 5q- and complex abnormalities. Molecular studies show persistence of the FLT3-ITD mutation. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of post-remission AML with 5q- and complex abnormalities is made. Further therapy is not recommended at this time, and close follow-up is recommended.
sample_name: Post-Remission AML with 5q- and Complex Abnormalities

description: A 65-year-old female with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) presented with worsening fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory tests revealed a leukocyte count of 205  109/L, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, platelets of 66  109/L, and a peripheral blood smear demonstrating 94% myeloblasts. Bone marrow biopsy confirmed accelerated phase CML. The patient was started on dasatinib and underwent allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The transcription includes information about the patient's medical history, symptoms, laboratory findings, diagnosis, treatment, and course of the disease.
transcription: 65-year-old female with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) presented with worsening fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory tests revealed a leukocyte count of 205  109/L, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, platelets of 66  109/L, and a peripheral blood smear demonstrating 94% myeloblasts. Bone marrow biopsy confirmed accelerated phase CML. The patient was started on dasatinib and underwent allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

description: Patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) presents with fatigue, fever, and bleeding. Complete blood count reveals white blood cell count of 26.9 k/mm^3, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelets of 21 k/mm^3. Bone marrow biopsy confirms AML with FLT3-ITD mutation. Treatment with induction chemotherapy is initiated.
transcription: Patient: 64 year old male with a history of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Presents with fatigue, night sweats, and pruritus. Physical exam is significant for pallor and splenomegaly. Complete blood count reveals white blood cell count of 15.9 k/mm^3, hemoglobin of 9.6 g/dL, and platelets of 58 k/mm^3. Peripheral blood smear shows atypical lymphoid cells. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypercellular marrow with 40% blasts, consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Cytogenetics reveals a complex karyotype with -7, del(5q), and +8. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) reveals an abnormal fusion of the ETO and AFF1 genes. Patient is started on induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin.
sample_name: Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia with Secondary AML

description: Patient presents with symptoms of dry eyes and discomfort in both eyes. Diagnosis of Meibomian gland dysfunction is made. Treatment with artificial tears and warm compresses is recommended.
transcription: Patient presents today for evaluation of symptoms of dryness and discomfort in both eyes, which he reports have been ongoing for several months. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. The anterior segments are quiet and there are no significant findings. The lids are slightly dry, and there are some horizontal lid laxity measurements of 4 mm on the right and 5 mm on the left. There is some inferior punctate epithelial erosion, which is more pronounced on the right. The meibomian glands appear to be clogged and there is some expression of mucous from the glands in both upper and lower lids. This is consistent with Meibomian gland dysfunction. The patient is instructed to use artificial tears as needed and warm compresses as needed.

description: Patient presents with complaints of blurred vision and floaters in the right eye. Examination reveals cataract formation and a vitreous floaters. Recommendation for cataract surgery is made.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of blurred vision and floaters in the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Pupils are 4 mm and reactive to light and accommodation. The intraocular pressures are 16 mm Hg in the right eye and 15 mm Hg in the left eye. The conjunctiva and lids are unremarkable. The sclera is white without signs of inflammation or edema. The cornea is clear without staining, and the anterior chamber is quiet with a 3+ cellular reaction and a 1.5 mm anterior chamber flare. The iris is brown without signs of inflammation. The patient's lens is mature, and a nuclear cataract is present. The vitreous is clear without signs of inflammation or hemorrhage. There is a 3+ vitreous floaters in the right eye. The macula is flat without drusen or exudates. The retinal vessels are unremarkable. The discs are healthy without signs of swelling or hemorrhage. The patient's right pupil measures 4 mm and the left pupil measures 4 mm. Dilation is complete in both eyes. The ocular motility is full in all directions. The extraocular muscles are without signs of tenderness, swelling, or limitation of motion. The eyelids are without signs of swelling, erythema, or limitation of motion. The orbital bones and soft tissues are without signs of swelling, erythema, or limitation of motion. The lacrimal apparatus is without signs of swelling, erythema, or limitation of motion. Recommend cataract surgery for the right eye.

description: Consultation for a 62-year-old female with a history of cataract surgery in both eyes presenting with ocular pain and reduced vision OU. Diagnosis: Acute anterior uveitis OU. Treatment: Prednisolone acetate and tobramycin drops BID OU for 6 weeks.
transcription: 62 year old female presents for evaluation of eye pain and decreased vision in both eyes. Past ocular history is significant for cataract surgery in both eyes. On exam, the patient has conjunctival injection and tearing. Slit lamp reveals 1+ cells in the anterior chamber and a muted aqueous flare. Intraocular pressure is 15 and 16 in the right and left eyes, respectively. Based on the history and exam, a diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis is made. The patient is prescribed prednisolone acetate and tobramycin drops twice daily for six weeks.

description: Patient presents with complaint of blurry vision and flashes in left eye. Exam reveals cataract and posterior vitreous detachment. Patient is advised to undergo cataract surgery.
transcription: Patient presents with a complaint of blurry vision in the left eye and flashes in the same eye. The patient's medical history is unremarkable. Visual acuity is 20/25 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements are full. Conjunctiva and lids are without pathology. The cornea is clear. Intraocular pressures are 14 in the right eye and 15 in the left eye. Dilated funduscopic examination of the right eye reveals a clear lens, cup to disc ratio of 0.6, and no pathology elsewhere in the fundus. The left eye reveals a nuclear sclerotic lens with a posterior subcapsular opacity, and a superior epiretinal membrane. The posterior vitreous is partially detached superiorly. The optic nerves and retinal vasculature are unremarkable. The patient is advised to undergo cataract surgery for the left eye.

description: Patient presents with blurred vision and redness in right eye. Diagnosis is conjunctivitis. Prescribed antibiotic drops.
transcription: Patient presents with a complaint of blurred vision and redness in the right eye, which he has had for 2 days. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Conjunctiva is injected and there is a follicular reaction in the right upper tarsal conjunctiva. The rest of the ocular exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis is bacterial conjunctivitis. Treat with TobraDex 0.3% ophthalmic ointment BID for 7 days.
sample_name: Ophthalmology Consult: Redness and Blurred Vision in Right Eye

description: Patient presents with blurry vision and redness in the left eye. Diagnosis of conjunctivitis is made. Treatment with antibiotic drops prescribed.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of blurry vision and redness in the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. The left eye shows diffuse conjunctival injection and a foreign body sensation. The cornea is clear. Intraocular pressure is 14 in the right eye and 16 in the left eye. Diagnosis: conjunctivitis. Treat: prescription for Tobra Drops (tobramycin and dexamethasone) QID x 14 days.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of blurred vision and floaters. Examination revealed cataracts in both eyes. Recommended surgery for cataracts.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of blurred vision and floaters. Visual acuity is 20/25 OD and 20/40 OS. Intraocular pressures are 14 mm Hg OD and 16 mm Hg OS. Pupils are 6 mm and reactive to light. Confrontational fields are full in both eyes. Dilated funduscopic examination reveals nuclear sclerotic lenses with a 3+ yellow tint OU. There is a 2.5 mm x 2.0 mm posterior subcapsular cataract OD and a 2.0 mm x 1.5 mm posterior subcapsular cataract OS. Irises are intact and without nodules or nevus. Conjunctivas are clear with no evidence of injection or discharge. The lids and lashes are unremarkable. The patient's symptoms and examination are consistent with cataracts in both eyes. Recommend surgery for cataracts.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of dry eye syndrome. Diagnosis is confirmed through Schirmer test and tear film break-up time measurements. Treatment with artificial tears and punctal occlusion is initiated.
transcription: Patient presents today for evaluation of his ocular symptoms. The patient is a 65-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass grafting in 2006. He denies any ocular history of note. His ocular review of systems is negative. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. His family history is positive for open-angle glaucoma in his mother. His social history is negative for tobacco or alcohol. On exam, his visual acuities are 20/20 in both eyes. Conjunctiva is intact in both eyes. Lids and lashes are unremarkable. Eyelids are aversion. Pupils are 4 mm and reactive to light and accommodation. Extraocular movements are full. Confrontational visual fields are full in both eyes. Slit lamp exam reveals no signs of inflammation, discharge, or foreign body. The anterior chambers are deep and quiet. The irises are intact with no signs of rubeosis. The lenses are clear. The intraocular pressures are 13 mm Hg OD and 14 mm Hg OS. Dilated fundus exam reveals cup to disc ratios of 0.6 OD and 0.7 OS. The disks are otherwise unremarkable. The maculas are intact. The foveal reflexes are present. The periphery is quiet. Based on the patient's symptoms, a Schirmer test and tear film break-up time were performed. The Schirmer test result was 5 mm in both eyes in 5 minutes. The tear film break-up time was 3 seconds OU. The patient was diagnosed with dry eye syndrome. Treatment with artificial tears and punctal occlusion was initiated.

description: Consultation for cataract surgery follow-up
transcription: Patient presented for follow-up after uncomplicated cataract surgery to the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Dilated fundus exam was unremarkable. Recommend annual exams.

description: Consultation for cataract surgery follow-up
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up after cataract surgery. Visual acuity 20/20 OD and OS. Intraocular lens in place and quiet. No evidence of any pathology. Return in 1 year.

description: Patient presents with complaints of blurred vision and eye pain. Examination reveals corneal ulcer and conjunctivitis. Treatment with antibiotic drops and steroid eye drops is initiated. Follow-up appointment is scheduled.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of blurred vision and eye pain in the right eye which began 3 days ago. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Intraocular pressures are 15 mm Hg in both eyes. Pupils are 6 mm and reactive to light. Conjunctiva is injected and there is a corneal epithelial defect in the right eye measuring 3 x 2 mm with surrounding stromal edema and purulent discharge. Fluorescein stains the epithelial defect and stromal ulcer. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. Differential diagnosis includes infectious keratitis. Treatment includes antibiotic drops q.h. And steroid eye drops b.i.d. Until the ulcer resolves. Patient will return in 1 week.

description: Patient presents with proteinuria and elevated creatinine levels. Diagnosis of chronic kidney disease is made. Management includes dietary modifications and medication therapy.
transcription: Patient presents to the nephrology clinic with a history of proteinuria and elevated creatinine levels. The patient reports no other symptoms related to the kidneys. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal a serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, urea nitrogen of 40 mg/dL, and a urinalysis demonstrating 3+ proteinuria with no hematuria or casts. Urine protein to creatinine ratio is 1.8 g/g. Renal ultrasound is normal. A diagnosis of chronic kidney disease is made based on the patient's laboratory studies and proteinuria. The patient is started on dietary modifications including a low sodium and low protein diet. Medication therapy with an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor is initiated to slow progression of the chronic kidney disease. The patient is scheduled to return for follow-up in 3 months for renal function monitoring.
sample_name: Chronic Kidney Disease Diagnosis and Management

description: Patient presents with abdominal pain and fever.
transcription: Patient is a 58-year-old male who presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of abdominal pain and fever. Vital signs are significant for a fever of 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit. Abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. White blood cell count is elevated at 15.8. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Patient is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is scheduled for appendectomy.
sample_name: Emergency Department Visit for Abdominal Pain and Fever

description: A 58-year-old female presented to the emergency department with acute onset of chest pain. Patient was given sublingual nitroglycerin and morphine. ECG showed ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Patient was diagnosed with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was emergently transferred to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for primary percutaneous coronary intervention.
transcription: 58-year-old female presented to the emergency department with acute onset of chest pain. Patient reported the pain as a pressure-like squeezing sensation in the center of the chest. Pain was radiating to the left shoulder and arm. Associated symptoms included diaphoresis and nausea. Vital signs were significant for a blood pressure of 148/74 mmHg. Patient was given sublingual nitroglycerin 0.4 mg and morphine 2 mg intravenously. In the emergency department, the patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Patient was diagnosed with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was emergently transferred to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
sample_name: Emergency Department Presentation for Chest Pain

description: Patient presented with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. Diagnosis: Acute Myocardial Infarction. Treatment: PCI with Stenting.
transcription: Patient is a 65 year old male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of substernal chest pain for the past 6 hours and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Vital signs are: Blood pressure 130/75, Pulse 80, Respirations 20, Temperature 98.4. Patient denies any significant past medical history. On physical exam, patient appears in no acute distress. Cardiac exam shows a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs or gallops. Respiratory exam shows good air movement and breath sounds without wheezing or rhonchi. Abdomen is benign. Extremities show no edema or deformity. Initial EKG shows sinus tachycardia with no ST segment deviations. CBC, Chem7, BMP and Cardiac enzymes have been ordered. Patient is being admitted to the hospital for further workup.

description: Report on a patient presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath.
transcription: Patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. Vital signs were stable. ECG showed sinus tachycardia. CXR revealed no acute abnormalities. Patient was diagnosed with unstable angina and admitted for further management.

description: Patient presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. Diagnosis: Acute Myocardial Infarction. Treatment: Nitroglycerin, Oxygen, Beta Blockers. Admitted to ICU.
transcription: Patient is a 55-year-old male who presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Vitals signs are: BP 135/75, Pulse 85, Respirations 20, O2 Saturation 98% on RA. The patient appears to be in distress with diaphragmatic breathing. On exam, the patient has a normal S1 and S2, with no murmurs or gallops. The patient has no significant skin findings. ECG shows an ST elevation in the anterior leads. Troponin I is 0.09 ng/mL. Diagnosis: Acute Myocardial Infarction. Treatment: Nitroglycerin, Oxygen, Beta Blockers. Admitted to ICU.
sample_name: Chest Pain and Shortness of Breath

description: Patient presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction. Treatment: Nitroglycerin, oxygen therapy, and admission to the cardiac care unit.
transcription: Patient presents to the emergency room complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. Vital signs are stable. Patient reports symptoms started 2 hours ago. EKG shows ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin I levels are elevated. Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction. Treatment: Nitroglycerin, oxygen therapy, and admission to the cardiac care unit.
sample_name: Chest Pain and Shortness of Breath

description: Patient presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction.
transcription: Patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient is a 65 year old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass graft in 2012. Vital signs on arrival were blood pressure of 140/80 mm Hg, pulse 85 beats per minute, respirations 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. The patient appeared uncomfortable but he was awake and alert. On physical examination, the patient had normal heart sounds without murmurs. The patient had normal breath sounds and a clear chest exam. Abdomen was benign. Extremities were without edema or deformity. ECG was performed and revealed an ST elevation in the anteroseptal leads. Troponin I was 0.23 ng/ml. The patient was diagnosed with myocardial infarction and was transferred to the cardiac care unit for further management.
sample_name: Emergency Department Visit for Chest Pain

description: Newborn's condition and treatment plan after birth complications.
transcription: Newborn baby, female, born via C-section at 36 weeks gestation due to fetal distress. Admitted to NICU for respiratory distress, desaturations, and apnea. Diagnosis: Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). Treatment: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and surfactant administered. Oxygen saturation levels improving. Parents informed of diagnosis and treatment plan.

description: Newborn's evaluation for feeding difficulties and reflux symptoms.
transcription: Pediatrician discusses newborn's history of poor feeding, spitting up, and occasional projectile vomiting. Discusses initial evaluation and plan, which includes feeding trials, thickening of feeds, and referral to gastroenterology if symptoms persist.
sample_name: Newborn Evaluation for Feeding Difficulties and Reflux Symptoms.

description: Newborn baby with respiratory distress admitted to the NICU for close monitoring and treatment
transcription: Baby boy born at 36 weeks gestational age via cesarean section to a mother with preeclampsia. Admitted to the NICU for close monitoring due to prematurity and respiratory distress. Initial weight 2120 grams. Temperature 36.4 degrees Celsius. Pulse 174 beats per minute. Respiratory rate 65 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Chest x-ray shows mildly hyperinflated lungs with no infiltrates. Started on nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) at 5 cm H2O. Initial ABG shows pH 7.28, PCO2 41 mm Hg, and PaO2 63 mm Hg. Started on intravenous (IV) dexamethasone for suspected respiratory distress syndrome. Followed by IV sodium bicarbonate for metabolic alkalosis. IV ampicillin and gentamicin for sepsis workup. IV methylprednisolone for suspected cerebral edema. Parents informed of baby's course and possible need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

description: Consultation for chronic pain management. Discussion of medication management and physical therapy options.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up complaint of chronic pain. Past medical history is significant for spinal stenosis and prior lumbar laminectomy. Patient reports improvement in symptoms after undergoing laminectomy but continues to experience pain in the lower back and right leg. Patient denies any radicular symptoms. Neurologic examination was unremarkable. Physical therapy has been initiated with some improvement in function. Medication regimen includes oxycodone 5mg q6h prn, tramadol 100mg q8h, and gabapentin 300mg q8h. Patient reports taking all medications as prescribed. Regimen is to be continued. Instructions for physical therapy to be continued.

description: A patient with a history of spinal cord injury presents with chronic pain in their lower extremities. The doctor discusses various pain management options, including medication, physical therapy, and nerve blocks. The patient is advised to follow a pain management plan and return for regular checkups.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up, complaining of chronic lower extremity pain. Patient has a history of spinal cord injury at T10. On exam, patient has decreased sensation below T10, as well as weakness in hip flexors and knee extensors. Pain is described as 8/10 in lower back and 9/10 in left lower extremity and 7/10 in right lower extremity. Pain is exacerbated by movement and improved with rest. Patient has tried oral medications, including gabapentin and oxycodone, with minimal relief. Doctor discusses options for pain management, including physical therapy, nerve blocks, and medication management. Patient is advised to follow a pain management plan and return for regular checkups.
sample_name: Chronic Lower Extremity Pain in Spinal Cord Injury Patient

description: Patient presented with chronic pain in the lower back. Diagnosis of degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis confirmed through imaging. Patient underwent lumbar fusion surgery. Post-operative pain management included opioids, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and physical therapy.
transcription: Patient presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of chronic lower back pain. The patient reports pain with sitting, standing, and walking, and describes the pain as a deep ache with radiating symptoms into the left leg. The patient denies any numbness or weakness in the lower extremities. The patient reports no history of trauma or injury to the area. The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both of which are well controlled with medication. The patient's family history is non-contributory. Physical examination reveals decreased lumbar spine range of motion with pain on palpation and movement. Straight leg raise testing is positive. Imaging studies reveal degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis at the L4-L5 level. The patient is scheduled for lumbar fusion surgery. Post-operative pain management includes opioids, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and physical therapy.

description: Record of patient's visit to a primary care physician for routine check-up
transcription: Patient presents for routine check-up. BP 130/80, Pulse 80, Weight 155 lbs, BMI 27.5. No acute complaints. Review of systems negative. PE and labs unremarkable. Prescription refills for metoprolol and levothyroxine. Schedule follow-up appointment in 6 months.

description: Consultation for hypertension and hyperlipidemia management.
transcription: Patient presents with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. BP 142/88, heart rate 82, BMI 31.1. Labs: Triglycerides 264, HDL 40, LDL 131, Glucose 108. Started lisinopril 20mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily.

description: Consultation for hypertension management with medication adjustment
transcription: Patient presents with complaint of high blood pressure. Blood pressure at home is 175/105. Medications include lisinopril 20mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily. BP at last visit was 180/110. Today's BP is 180/110. Decision is to increase lisinopril to 40mg daily and continue hydrochlorothiazide. Next appointment in 3 months.

description: Consultation for a 45-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia presenting with fatigue and headache.
transcription: Patient: Good afternoon, Doctor. Doctor: Good afternoon, Mrs. Smith. Patient: I have been having some problems lately. Doctor: What kind of problems? Patient: I have been feeling very tired and I have been having headaches. Doctor: How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? Patient: For about two weeks now. Doctor: And have you had any other symptoms besides fatigue and headache? Patient: Not really, no. Doctor: Alright. Let's start with your blood pressure. I'd like to take a reading. Patient: Alright. Doctor: (Takes blood pressure reading) Alright. Your blood pressure is a little on the high side. Patient: I know. That's why I'm here. Doctor: Alright. I'd also like to take a look at your heart. I'd like to listen to your heart first, and then I'd like to take your blood sugar level. Patient: Alright. Doctor: (Listens to heart) Alright. Your heart sounds normal. Let's move on to your blood sugar level. Patient: Alright. Doctor: (Takes blood sugar level) Alright. Your blood sugar level is within normal range. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Let's sit down and discuss your symptoms in more detail. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So, how have you been managing your hypertension and hypercholesterolemia? Patient: I have been taking medication regularly. Doctor: Alright. Have you noticed any changes in your symptoms since you started taking medication? Patient: Not really. Doctor: Alright. Based on your symptoms, I'd like to run some tests to rule out any underlying conditions. Patient: Alright. Doctor: I'd also like to prescribe some medication to help manage your symptoms in the meantime. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. I'll give you a prescription for some medication to help manage your symptoms, and I'll also schedule you for some tests. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. And we'll schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss the results of those tests. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Do you have any other questions or concerns? Patient: Not really, no. Doctor: Alright. If you think of anything, just give me a call. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Have a good day.

description: Consultation for a 46-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection. Patient was prescribed cephalexin and metronidazole. Follow-up appointment scheduled for 4 weeks.
transcription: 46-year-old female patient presents for routine follow-up. BP 136/82. Fasting glucose 126 mg/dL. Urine culture reveals E. Coli and yeast. Prescribe cephalexin and metronidazole for urinary tract infection. Schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks.

description: Consultation for hypertension and hyperlipidemia
transcription: Patient presented for routine follow-up. Blood pressure 152/94. Lipid panel: Total cholesterol 210, LDL 140, HDL 45, triglycerides 135. Prescribed lisinopril 10mg daily and simvastatin 20mg daily.

description: Record of a routine office visit for a patient with chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2.
transcription: Patient presents for routine follow-up. BP 142/88. Foot exam normal. Medications: lisinopril 20mg qd, metformin 500mg bid, rosuvastatin 20mg qd. Refills as needed. Return in 6 months.

description: Record of routine office visit for patient
transcription: Patient presents for routine office visit. Vital signs within normal limits. Patient reports no changes in health since last visit. Review of systems negative. Physical examination within normal limits. Prescriptions refilled as needed. Patient scheduled to return in 6 months.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and joint pain. Diagnosis is rheumatoid arthritis. Prescribed methotrexate and folic acid.
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of fatigue and joint pain. On examination, there is synovitis and swelling in the affected joints. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of rheumatoid factor. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made. The patient is prescribed methotrexate 25mg weekly and folic acid 1mg daily to manage the symptoms.
sample_name: Office Visit for Fatigue and Joint Pain

description: Consultation for hypertension and high cholesterol management
transcription: Patient presents for follow up. BP 142/90. Labs: Cholesterol 230, Triglycerides 150, HDL 35, LDL 150. Meds: Amlodipine, Simvastatin. Advised to continue diet and exercise regimen. Follow up in 6 months.

description: Treatment for plantar fasciitis and nail fungus
transcription: Patient presents with right heel pain and left foot nail fungus. Patient is a 57 year old male. Right foot X-ray is unremarkable. Diagnosis is plantar fasciitis. Patient is placed on anti-inflammatory medication and stretching exercises. Left foot shows thickening and discoloration of the nail plate. Diagnosis is onychomycosis. Treatment with oral antifungal medication is initiated. Patient is to return in 4 weeks for follow-up.

description: Treatment for plantar fasciitis and ingrown toenails.
transcription: Patient presents with chronic left heel pain for 4 months. Complains of pain on weightbearing activities and at rest. No history of trauma or injury. Past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type 2. Patient denies any other symptoms. On exam, the patient has tenderness to palpation over the medial aspect of the heel, without any localized swelling. The plantar fascia is tender to palpation. No other pertinent findings. Diagnosis: Plantar fasciitis. Patient presents with pain and swelling of the left second toe. Complains of pain on weightbearing activities and at rest. No history of trauma or injury. Past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type 2. Patient denies any other symptoms. On exam, the second left toe has a draining sinus tract with surrounding erythema and swelling. The nail plate is displaced. Diagnosis: Chronic ingrown toenail with recurrent infection.

description: Treatment for ingrown toenail in a 35-year-old male patient
transcription: Dr. Smith examined the feet of a 35-year-old male patient presenting with pain and swelling in the left great toe. Upon visual inspection, Dr. Smith observed the nail of the left great toe was curved and penetrating the skin, causing inflammation. Diagnosis: ingrown toenail. Treatment: nail trimming, nail matrix puncture, and antibiotics prescribed to prevent infection.

description: Consultation for foot and ankle pain in a 56-year-old female patient.
transcription: Patient presents with a 3-week history of left foot and ankle pain. She reports a history of flat feet, which she has had since childhood. Patient denies any trauma to the area. Exam shows mild edema to the left foot and ankle, as well as tenderness to palpation of the medial and lateral ankle joints. No erythema or warmth noted. X-rays of the left foot and ankle are unremarkable. Diagnosis: Left foot and ankle pain of unknown etiology.

description: Record of a patient with foot pain and ingrown toenail.
transcription: Patient presents with a complaint of pain in both feet. On exam, patient has an ingrown toenail on the left foot with purulent drainage. Right foot is red and tender. X-rays are ordered to rule out any fractures. Antibiotics are prescribed for the left foot. Patient is referred to podiatry for further management.

description: Treatment for plantar fasciitis and ingrown toenails
transcription: Patient presents with pain in left heel and right big toe. Patient has a history of plantar fasciitis. Exam reveals thickening of plantar fascia. Prescription for night splint and stretching exercises provided. Patient also has an ingrown toenail on right great toe. Nail debrided and antibiotic ointment prescribed. Review in 4 weeks.

description: Consultation for skin lesion on left upper arm. Lesion excised and sent for pathology. Pathology report reveals basal cell carcinoma. Patient scheduled for Mohs micrographic surgery.
transcription: Patient presents for follow up of a skin lesion on the left upper arm. The patient reports that the lesion has been present for several months and has been gradually increasing in size. On examination, there is a 1.5 cm papule with an irregular border on the left upper arm. The lesion is firm, non-tender, and fixed to the underlying subcutaneous tissue. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Given the clinical suspicion for a malignant lesion, the patient is scheduled for excisional biopsy. The lesion is excised and sent for pathology. Pathology reveals a basal cell carcinoma with a Breslow depth of 1.2 mm. The patient is scheduled for Mohs micrographic surgery.
sample_name: Skin Lesion on Left Upper Arm

description: Consultation for a 27-year-old female with a history of eczema and atopic dermatitis presenting with pruritus and erythematous plaques on the arms and legs. Diagnosis: Atopic dermatitis.
transcription: Patient presents for follow up for her dermatologic concerns. She is a 27 year old female with a history significant for eczema and atopic dermatitis. She is complaining of pruritus and erythematous plaques on her extremities, primarily her arms and legs. Exam is otherwise unremarkable. Diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is made.

description: Consultation with dermatologist for evaluation of multiple lesions on trunk and extremities. Diagnosis of seborrheic keratoses and solar lentigines. Recommended management of monitoring and sun protection.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up dermatology care. The patient describes multiple lesions on the trunk and extremities that he is concerned about. On exam, I find several seborrheic keratoses and solar lentigines. Recommended management is monitoring and sun protection.

description: Consultation with a dermatologist for a patient with recurrent eczema on the hands and feet. Diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. Prescription for topical corticosteroids and moisturizers.
transcription: Patient presents for follow up complaint of recurrent eczema on the hands and feet. Patient reports intermittent itching and redness with occasional vesicle formation. Patient denies any history of contact dermatitis or systemic symptoms. Examination reveals bilateral hand and foot dermatitis with hyperpigmentation and lichenification. Diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is made. Prescription for 0.1% hydrocortisone cream and moisturizer twice daily.

description: Consultation for rash on lower legs and feet. Biopsy of lesion. Diagnosis: Psoriasis. Prescription: Topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitor.
transcription: Patient presents with a rash on lower legs and feet. Lesion biopsied. Diagnosis: Psoriasis. Prescription: Topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitor.

description: Consultation for skin lesion on the right foot. Biopsy recommended. Referral to dermatologist for follow-up.
transcription: Patient presents with a skin lesion on the right foot. The lesion is discussed and a biopsy is recommended for further evaluation. The patient is referred to a dermatologist for follow-up.

description: Consultation for patient with recurrent eczema. Diagnosis: Atopic dermatitis. Prescription: Topical corticosteroid and emollient therapy.
transcription: Patient presents with recurrent eczema. Past medical history is significant for atopy. On exam, there is erythematous, xerotic, lichenified plaques on the antecubital fossae, forearms, and dorsal aspect of hands. Diagnosis: Atopic dermatitis. Treatment: Topical corticosteroid and emollient therapy.

description: Consultation for a 65-year-old female with a history of psoriasis and atopic dermatitis presenting with pruritic and scaling lesions on the upper extremities and trunk. Diagnosis: Psoriasis flare. Treatment: Prescribed betamethasone dipropionate and calcipotriene ointment.
transcription: 65-year-old female presenting with pruritic and scaling lesions on the upper extremities and trunk. Patient has a history of psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. Diagnosis is psoriasis flare. Prescribed betamethasone dipropionate and calcipotriene ointment.

description: A patient with a history of psoriasis presents with new lesions on the scalp, which have been worsened by exposure to sunlight. The dermatologist performs a biopsy of the lesions for pathological analysis.
transcription: Patient presents with a chief complaint of new lesions on the scalp. Patient has a history of psoriasis. Lesions appear to have been worsened by exposure to sunlight. Physical examination reveals plaques on the scalp with overlying scale. Biopsy of the lesions is performed for pathological analysis.

description: Consultation for a 62-year-old female with a history of melanoma and atypical nevi presenting with a newly-evolving, asymptomatic, 1.2 cm, irregularly-shaped, brown and red pigmented lesion on the left lower leg. Excisional biopsy performed.
transcription: 62 year old female presents for a dermatology consultation for a new lesion on the left lower leg. PM: 62 y/o female, melanoma O S '88, atypical nevi. Exam: T1N0M0 1.2cm brown/red irregularly shaped lesion on left lower leg. Biopsy performed. Pathology: melanocytic lesion, Breslow 0.7mm, mitotic activity 1/mm2, Clark level II, vertical growth phase present, ulceration present. Surgical excision recommended.

description: Consultation for skin lesion on the left foot. Biopsy taken and sent for pathology. Patient to return in 2 weeks for results.
transcription: Patient presents for evaluation of a skin lesion on the left foot. On exam, there is a 0.5 cm pink to red nodule on the plantar aspect of the left foot, located distal to the metatarsal heads. A punch biopsy was taken and sent for pathology. The patient will return in 2 weeks for results.

description: A patient presents with a rash on their left arm. The rash is red, itchy, and blistered. The patient has a history of eczema. The dermatologist diagnoses the rash as contact dermatitis and prescribes a steroid cream.
transcription: Patient presents with a rash on the left arm. The rash is erythematous, pruritic, and papulo-vesicular. Patient has a history of eczema. Diagnosis is contact dermatitis. Prescribed hydrocortisone 0.1% ointment.

description: Consultation for chronic hives in a 38 year old female. Discussion of treatment options and follow-up plan.
transcription: 38 year old female to routine dermatology follow up. Patient reports 2-3 week pruritic eruption in a bilateral symmetric distribution over the arms, trunk, and thighs. Lesions are papular and erythematous with surrounding edema. Denies associated symptoms. Patient reports some improvement with diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine. Denies exposure to new soaps or detergents. Medical and family history are non-contributory. Exam is notable for bilateral symmetric papular eruption in a symmetric distribution over the arms, trunk, and thighs. Some lesions are crusted. Remainder of exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis: Chronic hives. Discussion of treatment options and follow-up plan.

description: A patient presents with a rash on their left arm, which is itchy and red. Diagnosis is concluded as contact dermatitis. Prescription for antihistamines and steroid cream is provided.
transcription: Patient presents with a rash on their left arm, which is itchy and red. The patient reports no other symptoms. On examination, a red, scaly rash is present on the left upper arm. The rash is in a linear pattern, which suggests contact dermatitis. The patient reports working in a garden the day before the rash appeared. The patient denies any exposure to other potential allergens. Diagnosis: contact dermatitis. Treatment: antihistamines and steroid cream prescribed.

description: Consultation for skin lesion on left cheek. Excisional biopsy performed. Histopathology report: Basal cell carcinoma.
transcription: Patient presents for consultation regarding a skin lesion on the left cheek. The lesion measures 1.5 cm in greatest dimension. The lesion is firm, fixed, and irregular in shape. It is slightly tender to palpation. The lesion is a pink to light tan color. No bleeding, crusting, or drainage is noted. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histopathology reveals a basal cell carcinoma.

description: Procedure for root canal therapy and placement of a crown.
transcription: Patient presented for root canal therapy on #17 due to pain. Pulp vitality tested and found non-vital. A preoperative radiograph was taken and reveals a large periapical radiolucency. A mesiobuccal intra-canal radiograph was also taken. Rubber dam placed and local anesthetic administered. Access opened and working length measured at 25 mm. Canal negotiated with K files and irrigated with 5% sodium hypochlorite. Final irrigation with 17% EDTA and 5% sodium hypochlorite. Canal obturated with gutta percha points and AH Plus sealer. Access restored with temporary restoration. Patient will return for placement of a crown.

description: Procedure for the removal of impacted wisdom teeth
transcription: Patient presented with lower left wisdom tooth #16 (#32) impacted. Surgical extraction was performed under local anesthesia. Estimated blood loss was 50 cc. Postoperative instructions were reviewed and a prescription for ibuprofen and peridex rinse was provided.

description: Dental exam, filling replacement, X-ray, and oral hygiene instructions provided.
transcription: Patient presents for a dental exam and filling replacement. X-rays taken and patient is instructed in oral hygiene. Filling replaced in #3. Patient states that they have not been to a dentist in over 2 years.

description: Procedure for filling a cavity in a molar tooth using a composite material.
transcription: Patient presents with complaint of pain in left lower molar. Examination reveals a carious lesion in molar tooth number 17. The lesion is debrided and a liner is placed. The tooth is then etched and rinsed. The composite material is placed in two layers, light cured. Final polishing is completed.

description: Routine dental checkup and cleaning for a 35-year-old female patient.
transcription: Patient is a 35-year-old female. Routine dental checkup and cleaning performed. Teeth and gums appear healthy.

description: Routine dental check-up and cleaning procedure performed on a patient. The dentist examines the teeth, takes X-rays, and removes plaque and tartar. The patient is advised on proper oral hygiene and preventive measures.
transcription: Patient reported for a routine dental check-up and cleaning procedure. The dentist examined the teeth, took X-rays, and removed plaque and tartar. The patient was advised on proper oral hygiene and preventive measures. The teeth were found to be in good condition.
sample_name: Routine Dental Check-Up and Cleaning Procedure

description: Patient presents with pain in upper left molar. Root canal therapy performed. X-ray reveals periapical lesion. Prescribed antibiotics.
transcription: Patient presents with pain in upper left molar. The patient's medical history is obtained and a physical examination is performed. The patient complains of pain in the upper left molar. Periapical radiograph is taken and reveals a periapical lesion. Diagnosis of irreversible pulpitis is made. The patient is scheduled for root canal therapy. During the procedure, the patient experiences discomfort. The root canals are cleaned and shaped, and a medication is placed inside the root canals. The patient is instructed to return in one week for the final restoration. The patient is prescribed amoxicillin 500mg three times a day for 7 days to manage any possible infection.

description: Procedure performed by dentist to remove decayed material from a tooth and replace it with a filling.
transcription: Patient presents with complaint of tooth pain. Exam reveals caries in #17. Patient undergoes restoration of #17 with composite filling.

description: Regular dental check-up and cleaning procedure performed by a dentist. Patient receives x-rays and undergoes oral cancer screening. Cavity found and filled. Instructions provided for oral hygiene.
transcription: Patient presents for a regular dental check-up and cleaning. X-rays are taken and oral cancer screening is performed. Cavity found in tooth number 21. Patient is numbed and the cavity is filled. Instructions provided for oral hygiene. Next appointment scheduled for 6 months.

description: Root canal therapy performed on patient's maxillary left first molar. X-ray examination reveals periapical radiolucency. Filling material extrusion noted during removal. Post space prepared and filled with gutta percha. Temporary restoration placed.
transcription: Root canal therapy performed on patient's maxillary left first molar today. X-ray examination reveals a periapical radiolucency. Filling material extrusion was noted during removal. Post space was prepared and filled with gutta percha. A temporary restoration was placed.
sample_name: Root Canal Therapy on Maxillary Left First Molar

description: Patient presented with tooth pain and underwent root canal therapy on molar tooth. X-rays revealed apical periodontitis.
transcription: Patient presents with complaint of tooth pain. Exam reveals tenderness to palpation and percussion of molar tooth. Radiographs reveal apical periodontitis. Root canal therapy is indicated and performed on the molar tooth.

description: Dental examination and treatment for a patient with dental caries and periodontal disease. Procedures include scaling, root planing, and restoration of decayed teeth with composite fillings.
transcription: Patient presents for dental examination and treatment. Extraoral and intraoral exam reveals mild gingivitis, moderate periodontal disease, and several areas of dental caries. Scaling and root planing are performed on all surfaces of the teeth, including the interproximal regions. Following scaling, composite fillings are placed in teeth #2, 4, 15, and 17 to restore decayed enamel. Patient is scheduled for follow-up in 6 months.

description: Procedure performed for breast augmentation with silicone implants
transcription: Consultation for cosmetic surgery. Patient is a 40 year old female presenting with concerns about her breast size and shape. On exam, the patient has symmetrical breasts with mild ptosis. She is a good candidate for augmentation mammoplasty with silicone implants. Preoperative photos are taken. Preparation for surgery is discussed. Estimated blood loss is 50 cc. Estimated serum loss is 100 cc. Estimated fluid shift is 500 cc. Procedure is performed under general anesthesia. Postoperative recovery is discussed. Dressings and drains are placed. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Postoperative pain is managed with narcotics and anti-inflammatory medication. Antibiotics are prescribed. Follow up appointment is scheduled in 6 weeks.

description: Consultation for breast augmentation and Botox treatment
transcription: Patient comes in for consultation regarding breast augmentation and Botox treatment. Doctor examines patient's breasts and discusses options for implant size and type. Patient decides on 350cc silicone implants. Doctor also discusses areas for Botox treatment and patient decides on forehead and between the eyebrows. Doctor schedules surgery for next month.

description: Patient underwent a cosmetic surgery procedure to improve the appearance of their breasts.
transcription: Consultation with patient. Medical history obtained. Patient presents with concerns regarding the size and shape of her breasts. Examination reveals ptotic breasts with nipples at the level of the inframammary fold. 310 cc high profile silicone implants placed in subglandular and submuscular planes. Postoperative follow-up scheduled.

description: Patient underwent a facelift and neck lift procedure
transcription: Patient presents for consultation for facial rejuvenation. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, and osteoarthritis. Medications include lisinopril, levothyroxine, and ibuprofen as needed. Patient is a non-smoker and denies alcohol use. On exam, the patient appears 63 years of age, with moderate loose skin of the lower face and neck, and jowling. The patient undergoes a facelift and neck lift procedure, with the use of a sub-periosteal dissection technique. The surgery is performed under general anesthesia. Postoperative course is uncomplicated. The patient is seen for follow-up at 6 weeks postoperative. The patient is very satisfied with her results.

description: Patient undergoes cosmetic surgery to improve appearance
transcription: Consultation for 37 year old female with history of congenital ptosis and recent history of trauma to right eyelid. Patient is considering surgical correction of ptosis. Exam shows right ptosis of 3 mm and left ptosis of 1 mm. EOMs are full. Visual acuity is 20/20 OU. Surgical repair of ptosis performed under local anesthesia. Postoperative exam shows symmetrical lids at 3 mm. Follow up in 6 weeks.

description: Patient presents with left shoulder pain following a fall. Recommended course of treatment includes ultrasound, range of motion, and strengthening exercises.
transcription: Patient presents with left shoulder pain following a fall. The patient is a 65 year old female with a past medical history significant for osteoporosis and hypertension. The patient presents with left shoulder pain which she describes as a 7 out of 10 in intensity, worse with activity, and improves with rest. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation over the left shoulder. Strength is 5/5 in all rotator cuff muscles. Active range of motion is full. Passive range of motion is full. The patient has a positive impingement sign. X-rays of the shoulder were obtained and are unremarkable. An MRI of the shoulder is recommended for further evaluation of the left shoulder pain. Recommended course of treatment includes ultrasound, range of motion, and strengthening exercises.

description: Patient presented with left shoulder pain following a fall. Therapy consisted of passive range of motion exercises, strengthening exercises, and ultrasound therapy.
transcription: Patient presents with left shoulder pain following a fall. Passive range of motion exercises are initiated. Ultrasound therapy is applied to the affected area. Strengthening exercises are initiated.
sample_name: Left Shoulder Pain - Physical Medicine - Rehab

description: Patient with a history of spinal cord injury and quadriplegia undergoes physical medicine and rehabilitation therapy to improve mobility and function.
transcription: Patient presents for physical medicine and rehabilitation therapy for ongoing management of spinal cord injury sustained 6 months ago. Patient is a 33 year old male who is a quadriplegic at the C5 level. Patient reports some improvement in hand and wrist function since his last visit 2 weeks ago. Patient is able to perform wrist curls against gravity with some assistance. Patient is also able to perform shoulder abduction and external rotation against gravity with some assistance. Patient is provided with a home exercise program to continue these exercises. Patient is also provided with a manual wheelchair to use at home for improved mobility. Patient is encouraged to continue with physical medicine and rehabilitation therapy to further improve mobility and function.
sample_name: Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Therapy for Spinal Cord Injury

description: Patient presents with right shoulder pain and decreased range of motion due to rotator cuff injury. Treatment includes manual therapy, strengthening exercises, and modalities such as ultrasound and electrical stimulation.
transcription: Patient presents with right shoulder pain and decreased range of motion due to rotator cuff injury. On examination, there is weakness in external rotation and abduction. Manual therapy, including joint mobilization and myofascial release, is initiated to improve joint mobility and reduce pain. Strengthening exercises, focusing on the rotator cuff muscles, are prescribed to improve function and prevent future injury. Ultrasound and electrical stimulation are utilized to reduce inflammation and promote healing. The patient is also educated on proper posture and ergonomics to prevent further injury.
sample_name: Rotator Cuff Injury - Physical Medicine and Rehab

description: Consultation for a 47-year-old male with a history of sleep apnea and insomnia. Patient reports persistent symptoms despite use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy. Complains of daytime sleepiness and fatigue. Physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis of treatment-resistant sleep apnea is made and recommendation for an oral appliance is provided.
transcription: 47-year-old male presents for follow-up regarding his sleep disorder. He has a history of sleep apnea and insomnia. He reports persistent symptoms despite his use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy. He complains of daytime sleepiness and fatigue. Physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis of treatment-resistant sleep apnea is made and an oral appliance is recommended.

description: Consultation for sleep disturbances and evaluation of sleep disorders. Discussion of sleep hygiene, sleep apnea, insomnia, and restless leg syndrome. Recommendations for sleep studies and treatment options.
transcription: Patient presents with chronic insomnia and daytime sleepiness. Patient reports difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep, waking up multiple times throughout the night, and feeling unrefreshed upon awakening. Patient denies snoring or witnessed apneas. Patient reports occasional restless legs and periodic limb movements during sleep. Patient reports fatigue during the day, difficulty concentrating, and irritability. Patient reports no history of neurologic disorders or trauma. Patient reports no medication changes or recent travel. Patient reports no drug allergies. Patient reports smoking 1 pack per day for 20 years. Patient reports drinking alcohol daily. Patient reports caffeine use in the afternoon and evening. Recommend sleep hygiene education and sleep studies for sleep apnea and insomnia.

description: Treatment for obstructive sleep apnea with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The patient reports good compliance with CPAP, using it 6-7 nights a week. The patient denies any symptoms of sleep apnea. Nasal exam shows mild-moderate turbinate hypertrophy. Mild rhinitis. Mild sinusitis. Exam is otherwise normal. The patient's OSA is well controlled on his current settings of 8 cm/H2O on a Respironics Dreamstation machine.

description: Consultation for sleep apnea. Review of sleep study. Prescription for continuous positive airway pressure device.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up in sleep medicine. Review of sleep study from 11/12/19 demonstrates obstructive sleep apnea with a respiratory disturbance index of 61.3. Prescription for continuous positive airway pressure device is written.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of sleep apnea. Polysomnography confirms diagnosis and treatment with CPAP initiated. Follow-up sleep study shows improvement.
transcription: Patient presented to the sleep clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and loud snoring. The patient underwent a polysomnography study, which showed frequent obstructive apneas and hypopneas, as well as oxygen desaturations. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of sleep apnea was made. The patient was initiated on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy, and a follow-up sleep study was scheduled. The repeat polysomnography demonstrated a significant reduction in the number of apneas and hypopneas, as well as improved oxygen saturations.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. TSH level was suppressed, and free T4 levels were elevated. Diagnosis of Graves' disease was made, and the patient was started on antithyroid medication. Follow-up testing will be done to monitor thyroid function.
transcription: Patient presented to the endocrinology clinic with symptoms of hyperthyroidism including weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Her symptoms began approximately six weeks ago. On examination, she was found to have a regular rhythmic heart rate, and her neck was noted to be slightly enlarged. She has a history of Graves' disease, which was previously treated with radioactive iodine. The patient's symptoms and history are suggestive of a recurrence of her disease. Her TSH level was found to be suppressed at 0.02 IU/mL (reference range: 0.4-4.0), and her free T4 level was elevated at 3.6 ng/dL (reference range: 0.8-1.8). Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Graves' disease was made. The patient was started on antithyroid medication, and she will undergo follow-up testing to monitor her thyroid function.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. TSH suppressed, T3 and T4 levels elevated. Diagnosis of Graves' disease confirmed. Treated with antithyroid medication and radioactive iodine therapy. Follow-up monitoring recommended.
transcription: Patient presented to the endocrinology clinic today with complaints of weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. The patient has a history of Graves' disease, which was treated with antithyroid medication and radioactive iodine therapy several years ago. On examination today, the patient's vital signs were normal and physical exam was unremarkable. Thyroid function tests were ordered, which revealed a suppressed TSH level, as well as elevated T3 and T4 levels, consistent with hyperthyroidism. The patient was diagnosed with a recurrence of Graves' disease. Antithyroid medication was initiated, and the patient was advised to undergo radioactive iodine therapy for definitive treatment. Follow-up monitoring will be recommended to ensure resolution of symptoms and normalization of thyroid function.
sample_name: Endocrinology Clinic Visit for Recurrent Hyperthyroidism

description: A consultation between a patient and an endocrinologist discussing the patient's type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and elevated cholesterol levels. The doctor reviews the patient's medical history, performs a physical examination, and recommends medication and lifestyle changes to manage the patient's conditions.
transcription: Patient: Good morning, Dr. Jones. How are you today? Doctor: Good morning, Susan. How are you feeling today? Susan: I'm doing okay. Doctor: Alright, let's get started. Can you tell me a little bit about why you came in today? Susan: Yes, I have type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and my cholesterol levels have been a bit elevated. Doctor: Okay, those are all conditions that we can manage. First, let's talk about your diabetes. How's your blood sugar been? Susan: It's been pretty consistent, but I've been having some trouble controlling it with diet and exercise alone. Doctor: Alright, we'll probably need to start you on some medication for that. We'll also be discussing lifestyle changes to help manage your condition. Susan: Okay. Doctor: Moving on to your high blood pressure, how's that been? Susan: It's been a bit high, but I've been working on managing it with diet and exercise. Doctor: That's a good start. We'll want to keep a close eye on that and may need to adjust your medication as needed. Susan: Alright. Doctor: Lastly, your cholesterol levels. Have you had any recent tests done? Susan: Yes, my doctor ran some tests a few months ago and found that my cholesterol was a bit high. Doctor: Alright, we'll be discussing medication options for that as well. Susan: Okay. Doctor: Before we move forward, I'd like to review your medical history with you. Can you tell me about any other conditions you've had in the past or any surgeries you've had? Susan: I've had my gallbladder removed, and I've had some issues with my thyroid in the past, but it's been stable for a few years now. Doctor: Alright, I see. Let's move on to the physical examination. I'll need to take your blood pressure, pulse, and listen to your heart and lungs. Then we'll do a blood sugar test to check your levels. Susan: Alright. Doctor: After that, we can discuss medication and lifestyle changes in more detail. Susan: Alright. Doctor: Alright, let's get started. Your blood pressure is a bit high today, but we'll keep an eye on that. Your pulse is regular, and your heart and lungs sound good. Your blood sugar is a bit elevated, which is in line with your diabetes diagnosis. Based on all of this, we'll be starting you on medication for your diabetes and high blood pressure. We'll also be discussing some lifestyle changes to help manage your conditions. Susan: Alright, thank you. Doctor: You're very welcome, Susan. Remember to keep up with your regular checkups and follow your medication and lifestyle plans as prescribed. Susan: I will do that. Doctor: Alright, we'll see you again in a few months to check in on your progress. Susan: Thank you, Doctor. Doctor: Anytime, Susan. Have a good day.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia. Labs show low glucose levels. Diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. Prescribed insulin therapy.
transcription: Patient presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia. The patient reports sweating, shakiness, and confusion. Vital signs are within normal limits. Labs are drawn and show a glucose level of 54 mg/dL. The patient reports a history of diabetes mellitus and is currently not on any medications. The patient is instructed to eat a snack and will have labs repeated in one hour. One hour later, the patient returns for labs. The patient reports no further symptoms. Vital signs remain within normal limits. Labs show a glucose level of 123 mg/dL. Diagnosis of diabetes mellitus is confirmed. The patient is started on insulin therapy.

description: Management of patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Discussion of insulin resistance, glycemic control, lipid profiles, and cardiovascular risk factors. Prescription of metformin and glipizide. Follow-up appointments scheduled.
transcription: Patient presents with type 2 diabetes mellitus. HbA1c 7.2%. Insulin resistance present. Glycemic control and lipid profiles are suboptimal. Cardiovascular risk factors include hypertension and obesity. Metformin 1000mg BID and glipizide 5mg daily initiated. Follow-up appointment scheduled in 3 months.

description: Patient is a 45-year-old female with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism presenting with symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and heat intolerance for the past 6 months. She underwent laboratory testing which revealed elevated levels of TSH, FSH, and LH, as well as a low level of free T4. Diagnosis of hypothyroidism was made and treatment with levothyroxine was initiated. Patient was also advised to make lifestyle modifications to manage her symptoms of diabetes mellitus and obesity.
transcription: 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of fatigue, weight gain, and heat intolerance for the past 6 months. Her past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. On examination, patient's BMI is 35 kg/m2. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated TSH of 10.5 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L), FSH of 30 mIU/mL (normal range: 5-25 mIU/mL), and LH of 25 mIU/mL (normal range: 5-25 mIU/mL). Free T4 is low at 0.7 ng/dL (normal range: 0.8-1.8 ng/dL). Diagnosis of hypothyroidism is made and patient is started on levothyroxine. She is advised to make lifestyle modifications to manage her diabetes mellitus and obesity.

description: Patient presented with symptoms of hypoglycemia and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. Treatment plan included dietary modifications and medication management.
transcription: Patient presented to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of sweating, tremors, and dizziness. The patient reported these symptoms occurred in the morning, prior to breakfast. The patient's fasting blood glucose was 42 mg/dL. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient was instructed to follow a diabetic diet and medication management was initiated.

description: Patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for routine follow-up. Hemoglobin A1c at 7.2%. BP 140/80. Pulse 82. Weight 85 kg. Medications: Metformin 500 mg BID, Glipizide 5 mg daily, Losartan 100 mg daily, Simvastatin 40 mg daily, Aspirin 81 mg daily, Furosemide 40 mg daily, Omeprazole 20 mg daily.
transcription: Patient presents for routine follow-up. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient's HbA1c is 7.2%. Blood pressure is 140/80. Pulse is 82. The patient weighs 85 kg. The patient is on metformin 500 mg BID, glipizide 5 mg daily, losartan 100 mg daily, simvastatin 40 mg daily, aspirin 81 mg daily, furosemide 40 mg daily, and omeprazole 20 mg daily.

description: A patient with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with hyperglycemia and is started on insulin therapy. Blood glucose monitoring is recommended for self-management. The patient is advised to follow a diabetic diet and exercise program. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine, consistent with hypothyroidism. Levothyroxine is initiated for replacement therapy. The patient reports symptoms of hot flashes and is diagnosed with menopause. Estrogen replacement therapy is prescribed for management.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up care. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current complaint is hyperglycemia. On examination, blood glucose is 250 mg/dL. Insulin therapy is initiated and the patient is instructed to monitor blood glucose levels at home. Diabetic diet and exercise program are recommended. Laboratory tests show TSH 6.7 mIU/L (normal 0.55-5.5 mIU/L) and free thyroxine 1.0 ng/dL (normal 0.8-1.8 ng/dL), consistent with hypothyroidism. Levothyroxine 50 mcg daily is prescribed for replacement therapy. The patient reports hot flashes. Menopause is diagnosed and estrogen replacement therapy is initiated.

description: Discussion of patient with type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. Prescription for insulin and thyroid replacement therapy.
transcription: Patient presenting with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. Currently on metformin, glipizide, and levothyroxine. HgbA1c 7.5%. Lipid panel shows elevated triglycerides and LDL. Prescribed insulin 10 units BID and levothyroxine 100mcg daily.

description: A 35-year-old female with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with fatigue and weight gain. Laboratory studies revealed an elevated fasting plasma glucose level and glycosylated hemoglobin. The patient was started on insulin therapy and dietary counseling.
transcription: 35-year-old female presented to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of fatigue and weight gain. Her past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. On presentation, her fasting plasma glucose was 192 mg/dL, and her glycosylated hemoglobin was 9.2%. The patient was started on insulin therapy and dietary counseling.
sample_name: Endocrinology Visit for Fatigue and Weight Gain

description: Surgical intervention for obesity management
transcription: Patient presented for evaluation of morbid obesity with BMI of 47.6 kg/m2. Recommended a laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure. Surgery proceeded uneventfully. Patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged on postoperative day 2.
sample_name: Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass for Morbid Obesity

description: Record regarding a bariatric surgery procedure
transcription: Patient presented for bariatric surgery consultation. BMI 45 kg/m2. Medical history significant for hypertension, GERD, hypothyroidism, and sleep apnea. Medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, omeprazole, and levothyroxine. Patient was educated on the different types of bariatric surgery and elected for a sleeve gastrectomy. Preoperative labs and imaging were unremarkable. Surgery was successful with an estimated resection of 75%. Postoperative course was uneventful. Patient was discharged home on postoperative day 2.

description: A medical record discussing a bariatric surgery procedure for weight loss.
transcription: Patient presents for consultation regarding morbid obesity. BMI 46.9. Past medical history significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, and coronary artery disease. Medications include metformin, lisinopril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and simvastatin. Patient reports daily sitz baths and daily use of topical corticosteroids for pruritus ani. Family history significant for obesity and hypertension. Patient reports a 50 lb weight gain over the past year despite diet and exercise. Patient reports difficulty with activities of daily living due to obesity. Patient reports a BMI of 46.9. Patient is motivated to improve her health. Patient is not a smoker or a tobacco user. Patient has had a hysterectomy. Patient understands risks and benefits of surgery. Patient would like to proceed with a sleeve gastrectomy. Pre-op labs are within normal limits. Surgical plan is for a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. Estimated blood loss is less than 50 cc. Anticipated operative time is less than 90 minutes. Post-op pain will be managed with a PCA pump. Antibiotics will be administered. Deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis will be administered. Patient will be instructed to follow a liquid diet for the first 2 weeks post-op. Patient will be discharged on day 1 post-op. Follow up will be in 1 week. Patient understands these instructions and will adhere to them.

description: Surgical procedure for weight loss management
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up 6 weeks post-bariatric surgery. Patient reports good weight loss progress. No complaints. BMI 31.9. Labs and exam normal. Recommend follow-up in 6 months.

description: Medical report for work-related injury claim
