transcription: Patient presented with complaint of left wrist pain following a fall at work. Pain rated as 8/10. Diagnostic testing revealed a distal radius fracture. Patient underwent closed reduction and internal fixation. Follow-up care recommended.

description: Medical evaluation for work-related injury
transcription: Patient presents for medical evaluation due to a work-related injury. The patient reports an injury to the left elbow sustained while lifting a heavy object at work. Examination reveals tenderness over the lateral aspect of the elbow with full range of motion. X-rays of the elbow are negative for fracture. Diagnosis is left elbow tendinitis due to work injury. Treatment includes rest, ice, compression, and elevation of the elbow. The patient will be followed up in 4 weeks.

description: Medical evaluation for work injury.
transcription: Patient presents for medical evaluation for work injury. Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain. History: Patient is a 54-year-old male construction worker who fell from a ladder two weeks ago. He reports pain in the right shoulder which worsens with overhead activity. He denies any neck pain or symptoms in the left arm. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Physical exam: Vital signs within normal limits. Shoulder exam demonstrates pain with range of motion. Strength and sensation are intact. Neck exam is within normal limits. X-ray of the right shoulder was obtained and demonstrates a right posterior shoulder dislocation. Impression: Right posterior shoulder dislocation due to fall from a ladder two weeks ago.

description: Record of Workers' Compensation evaluation and treatment for musculoskeletal disorder
transcription: [Patient Name] was seen for a Workers' Compensation evaluation today. The patient presents with a musculoskeletal disorder of his right elbow, which is causing him pain and weakness. The patient states that he fell from a ladder while at work and landed on his outstretched right arm. He has been having pain and weakness in his right elbow since the injury. Physical exam of the right elbow revealed normal range of motion, swelling, and tenderness to palpation over the lateral epicondyle. X-rays of the right elbow were obtained and revealed no abnormality. Diagnosis of right lateral epicondylitis was made. The patient was prescribed ibuprofen 800mg every 8 hours as needed for pain, and a physical therapy referral was made.

description: Medical record for work-related injury claim
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of low back pain following a work-related injury. Exam reveals tenderness to palpation in the lumbar spine. Diagnosis of lumbar strain is made. Treatment includes physical therapy and pain medication.

description: Medical report for a workplace injury case.
transcription: Patient presents with a chief complaint of right upper extremity injury sustained while operating a forklift. Pain is described as sharp and radiates into the forearm. No neurologic symptoms are present. Patient is diagnosed with a right radial nerve contusion and is recommended to wear a sling for comfort and to follow up with a hand therapist for further evaluation and treatment.

description: Record of chiropractic adjustment session for patient with neck pain.
transcription: Patient presents with chronic neck pain. Initial x-rays show degenerative joint disease in the cervical spine. Today, patient reports 5/10 pain in the neck. Spinal manipulation is performed on C4-C5 and C5-C6. Patient reports immediate relief of pain. Schedule follow-up in 4 weeks.
sample_name: Chiropractic Adjustment Session for Neck Pain

description: Patient presents with lower back pain for 2 weeks. Initial chiropractic adjustment provided. Patient reports immediate improvement.
transcription: Patient presents with lower back pain for 2 weeks. Initial chiropractic adjustment provided to the lumbar spine. Patient reports immediate improvement in symptoms.
sample_name: Chiropractic Adjustment for Lower Back Pain

description: Consultation with a chiropractor for back pain.
transcription: Patient presents with chief complaint of right lower back pain. Denies any trauma or injury. Onset insidious 6 weeks ago. Pain is a 5 out of 10, worsened with sitting, relieved with lying down. No radiation or numbness. Medical history significant for asthma, GERD, and hypothyroidism. Meds: Singular, albuterol inhaler as needed, Synthroid, and Zantac. Allergies: Penicillin. Exam: Spine: Neurologic Intact. No step or spinous process tenderness. Range of motion pain free. Musculature: Lumbar paraspinal muscles tender to palpation. Remainder of exam unremarkable. Impression: Back strain.

description: Consultation with chiropractor for back pain. Initial evaluation and treatment plan.
transcription: Patient presents with chief complaint of lower back pain. Onset 2 weeks ago. Aggravating factors include prolonged sitting. Alleviating factors include changing positions. Denies radiculopathy or numbness. Medical history includes hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation in the lumbosacral region. Straight leg raise test is negative. Reflexes are 2+. Neurologic exam is otherwise unremarkable. Diagnosis: Lumbar Strain. Treatment plan includes chiropractic adjustments, therapeutic exercises, and stretches. Return for re-evaluation in 4 weeks.

description: Patient presents with lower back pain. Chiropractic adjustments provided. Patient reports improvement.
transcription: Patient presents with lower back pain. The patient is a 35-year-old male who reports pain in the lumbar region with onset 2 weeks ago. The pain is described as a deep ache, worse with sitting and lifting. There is no radicular pain or paresthesias. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury. The neurologic exam is unremarkable. Range of motion of the lumbar spine is full. Palpation of the lumbar paraspinal muscles reveals spasm. Chiropractic adjustments are provided, specifically a Diversified technique to the L5-S1 segment. The patient reports immediate relief of symptoms.
sample_name: Chiropractic Adjustment for Lower Back Pain

description: Consultation for back pain
transcription: Patient presents with complaints of lower back pain for several weeks. History reveals a prior episode of back pain in 2010. Patient reports some relief with over-the-counter medication. Physical exam shows some tenderness over the lower back. Spinal manipulation is performed to the lumbar spine. Patient reports some immediate relief.

description: Treatment for lower back pain and neck pain using spinal manipulation and adjustments.
transcription: Patient presents with lower back pain and neck pain. Spinal manipulation and adjustments provided to alleviate symptoms.
sample_name: Chiropractic Appointment for Lower Back and Neck Pain

description: Record of chiropractic treatment for back pain
transcription: Patient presents with a chief complaint of lower back pain for the past 3 months. History reveals that the pain is dull and achy, worst in the morning and improves with activity. No radiation or numbness. Patient reports no bowel or bladder dysfunction. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism. Current medications include lisinopril and levothyroxine. Physical exam reveals a well-developed male in no acute distress. Spine shows hypolordosis with forward head posture. Straight leg raise is negative to 45 degrees bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetrical. Neurologic exam is otherwise unremarkable. Diagnosis: Lumbar strain. Treatment: Spinal manipulation and home exercises.
sample_name: Chiropractic Treatment for Lower Back Pain

description: Patient presents with lower back pain. Treatment includes chiropractic adjustments and stretches.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up visit for lower back pain. On exam, the patient has some tenderness to palpation in the lumbar spine. Range of motion is somewhat restricted. X-rays were obtained and show some degenerative changes in the lower back. Treatment will include chiropractic adjustments and some stretches. The patient is to avoid heavy lifting for the time being.
sample_name: Chiropractic Follow-up for Lower Back Pain

description: Patient presents with lower back pain for 3 weeks, reports mild relief with ice and over-the-counter pain medication. Chiropractor performs spinal manipulation and exercises to strengthen core muscles.
transcription: Patient comes in today complaining of lower back pain that he has been experiencing for the past three weeks. He reports that the pain is mild, but has not completely gone away. He mentions that he has been using ice and over-the-counter pain medication to alleviate some of the discomfort. Upon examination, I note that the patient has limited range of motion in his lower back and some tenderness in the area. I perform a spinal manipulation to help alleviate any misalignments in his spine that may be contributing to his pain. I also provide him with some exercises to help strengthen his core muscles, which will help support his lower back and prevent future episodes of pain.
sample_name: Chiropractic Visit for Lower Back Pain

description: Description: A 45-year-old female presents with a 2-month history of joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning. Past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism. Medications include levothyroxine. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness in multiple joints, including the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints of the hands, as well as the wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles. Rheumatoid factor is elevated. X-rays of the hands and feet are consistent with erosive disease. Diagnosis: Rheumatoid arthritis.
transcription: History: A 45-year-old female presents with a 2-month history of joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning. The pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. She denies any systemic symptoms, such as fever, weight loss, or night sweats. Past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism. She has been taking levothyroxine for 5 years. Medications: Levothyroxine 100 mcg daily. Allergies: NKDA. Family history: Mother and sister with rheumatoid arthritis. Social history: She works as a legal secretary. Physical examination: Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/80, pulse 84, respirations 18, temperature 37.2 degrees Celsius. General: Well-appearing, obese female. Skin: Warm, dry, without rash or lesions. Head, ears, nose, throat: Normal. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation and percussion, without rales, wheezes, or crackles. Abdomen: Soft, nondistended, with benign findings. Extremities: Joint swelling and tenderness in multiple joints, including the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints of the hands, as well as the wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles. Neurologic: Alert and oriented, with normal cranial nerves. Strength, sensation, and reflexes are normal. Diagnostic tests: Rheumatoid factor: 82 IU/mL (normal < 14). HLA-DRB1 alleles: *01, *04, *07, *10, *11, *13, *14, *15. Anti-CCP: 650 ng/mL (normal < 50). ANA: Negative. X-rays of the hands and feet: Erosive disease involving the hands, including the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints, as well as the wrists and carpometacarpal joints. Radiographic stage: III. Diagnosis: Rheumatoid arthritis.

description: Patient presents with joint pain and swelling. Rheumatoid factor is positive. Diagnosis: rheumatoid arthritis.
transcription: Patient presents with joint pain and swelling. The patient is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history significant for asthma and hypertension. Her symptoms began 6 months ago and have been progressive. She reports morning stiffness and fatigue. Her joints involved include the metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, wrists, and knees. She denies any fevers or weight loss. She reports no recent sick contacts. Her medications include inhaled albuterol and lisinopril. Her physical examination is notable for 10/14 tenderness to palpation of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the right hand and metacarpophalangeal joints of the left hand. She has a right wrist that is mildly swollen and tender to palpation and passive motion. She has 3/388 swelling of the proximal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. She has 1/388 swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the left thumb. She has no swelling or tenderness of her knees. Her range of motion is full. Her labs are notable for a positive rheumatoid factor at 61 IU/mL. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 41 mm/h. X-rays of her hand and feet are unremarkable. Based on her history, exam, and laboratory studies, she meets the 1987 revised criteria for the classification of rheumatoid arthritis. I would recommend initiating therapy with methotrexate 25 mg weekly.

description: Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis in a 42-year-old female patient with methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine. Discussion of symptom management and monitoring for potential side effects.
transcription: Rheumatology consultation with Dr. Smith for a 42-year-old female with rheumatoid arthritis. Patient reports worsening joint pain and stiffness, particularly in her hands and feet. She has been taking methotrexate 15 mg weekly and hydroxychloroquine 200 mg daily for the past 6 months. Labs show an elevated ESR at 45 mm/hr and CRP at 12 mg/L. X-rays show joint space narrowing and erosions in the hands and feet. Patient is experiencing fatigue and some low-grade fevers. Plan is to continue methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine with close monitoring for potential side effects such as liver function abnormalities, neutropenia, and infection.

description: Consultation for a 65 year old female with a 1 year history of joint pain and morning stiffness. Exam reveals active synovitis and erosions in the hands and feet. Diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made. Treatment with methotrexate is initiated.
transcription: 65 year old female presents to the rheumatology clinic with complaints of joint pain and morning stiffness for one year. Her symptoms are worse in the mornings and improve throughout the day. She denies any fevers, weight loss, or rashes. She reports no recent sick contacts. She takes no medications regularly. Her medical history is significant for hypothyroidism. Her family history is unremarkable. On physical exam, she has active synovitis and erosions in the hands and feet. X-rays reveal joint space narrowing and periarticular osteopenia. Labs are significant for a positive rheumatoid factor. Given her history, exam, and lab results, a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made. Methotrexate is initiated at a dose of 15mg weekly.

description: Summary of a medical record related to rheumatology
transcription: Patient is a 62-year-old female with a 3-year history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presenting with a 2-week history of worsening right wrist pain. She denies any other joint symptoms. She reports fatigue but denies fever, weight loss, or night sweats. She is taking methotrexate 25mg weekly and folic acid 1mg daily. Her last methotrexate dose was 5 days ago. She is allergic to penicillin. Physical exam is significant for tender right wrist joint. Labs show a CBC with an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 12.9 x 10^9/L. ESR is 58 mm/hr. RF is negative. CRP is 1.4 mg/dL. X-ray of the wrist shows joint space narrowing and periarticular osteopenia. Diagnosis: Active RA of the right wrist.

description: Treatment plan for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis
transcription: Patient presents with symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis. Diagnosis confirmed through lab tests and imaging. Treatment plan includes methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone for symptom management. Patient to undergo regular monitoring for disease progression and side effects of medication.

description: A 65-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and stiffness. Exam reveals multiple joint swellings with synovitis. Laboratory studies show a positive rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Diagnosis is rheumatoid arthritis.
transcription: Patient is a 65-year-old female who presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and stiffness. On examination, multiple joints are swollen and show signs of synovitis. Laboratory studies reveal a positive rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made.

description: Consultation for a 66-year-old female with a 6-month history of polyarthralgia and morning stiffness. Rheumatoid factor positive. X-rays of the hands and feet show erosive changes. Diagnosis: rheumatoid arthritis.
transcription: 66 year old female presents with a 6 month history of polyarthralgia and morning stiffness. Rheumatoid factor is positive. X-rays of the hands and feet demonstrate erosive changes. Diagnosis: rheumatoid arthritis.

description: Consultation for a 46-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, fibromyalgia, and psoriasis. The patient reports worsening arthralgias, fatigue, and morning stiffness in her hands and feet. Labs show a mildly elevated ESR and CRP. X-rays of the hands show erosions and joint space narrowing. Rheumatoid factor is negative. Treatment includes methotrexate and leflunomide.
transcription: 46-year-old female presenting for routine follow-up. She has a history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, fibromyalgia, and psoriasis. Denies any acute illnesses or trauma. The patient reports worsening arthralgias, fatigue, and morning stiffness in her hands and feet. She reports some stiffness in the morning that resolves by noon. She denies any joint swelling or deformities. The patient is on methotrexate 15mg weekly and leflunomide 20mg daily. She reports some joint stiffness on the methotrexate but feels that her rheumatoid arthritis is well-controlled overall. Her fibromyalgia is well-managed with gabapentin. She reports good control of her psoriasis with biologic therapy every 4 weeks. Her psoriatic arthritis is also well-controlled on methotrexate and leflunomide. She denies any new symptoms. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Physical exam is significant for some tenderness to palpation over her metacarpophalangeal joints and metatarsophalangeal joints bilaterally. She has some swelling and stiffness in these joints, but no deformity. Her range of motion is full. Her hands and feet are warm and erythematous. Labs show a mildly elevated ESR of 21 and a mildly elevated CRP of 4. Her rheumatoid factor is negative. X-rays of the hands show erosions and joint space narrowing. Her chest x-ray is unremarkable. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone and serum protein electrophoresis are within normal limits. She is up to date on her immunizations, including pneumococcal, influenza, and tdap. She denies any tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. Her family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in her mother. Her mother is doing well on methotrexate. She has no other significant family history. Her social history is significant for a dog at home. Her occupation is sedentary. Her review of systems is otherwise negative. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her labs and x-rays will be reviewed at the next visit.

description: Case of a 48-year-old female with a 2-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presenting with joint pain and stiffness. Physical exam revealed synovitis in the wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints. Lab results showed an elevated rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. Diagnosis of active rheumatoid arthritis was made and treatment with methotrexate was initiated.
transcription: 48-year-old female presenting with a 2-year history of joint pain and stiffness. PMH is significant for rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed 2 years ago. Current medications include celecoxib 400mg bid PRN and ibuprofen 600mg tid PRN. Vital signs within normal limits. Exam shows synovitis in the right wrist and 3rd, 4th, and 5th metacarpophalangeal joints. Labs show rheumatoid factor 70 IU/mL (0-14 IU/mL) and anti-CCP 525 U/mL (0-5 U/mL). CBC, BMP, and urinalysis are unremarkable. Diagnosis: active rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment: start methotrexate 25mg weekly.
sample_name: Active rheumatoid arthritis in a 48-year-old female

description: Patient presents with joint pain and swelling. Rheumatoid factor is positive. Diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment with methotrexate and prednisone.
transcription: Patient presents with joint pain and swelling. The patient is a 55 year old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism. The patient denies any fevers, weight loss, or night sweats. The patient endorses a 6 week history of joint pain and swelling in her left hand and left hip. The patient reports morning stiffness in her left hip and left hand. The patient rates her pain as 8 out of 10. The patient denies any recent sick contacts or travel. The patient's vitals signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient has a left hand DIP joint effusion and synovitis. The patient has a left hip effusion. The patient has mild synovitis in her right knee. Laboratory studies are pending. Rheumatoid factor is positive at 70. Anti-CCP is negative. CBC, CMP, ESR, and CRP are pending. X-rays are pending. The patient is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. The patient is started on methotrexate 25mg weekly and prednisone 10mg daily. The patient is scheduled to return in 2 weeks for re-evaluation.

description: Patient presents with joint pain and inflammation. Diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis confirmed through laboratory tests. Treatment plan includes disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs and corticosteroids.
transcription: Patient presents with a chief complaint of joint pain and inflammation. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness in multiple joints, most notably the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints of the hands, as well as the second and third metatarsophalangeal joints of the feet. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein, as well as a positive rheumatoid factor. X-rays of the hands and feet show periarticular osteopenia and joint space narrowing. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made. The patient is started on a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug, such as methotrexate or leflunomide, as well as a corticosteroid, such as prednisone, to manage symptoms and slow disease progression.

description: Case presentation: A 45-year-old female with a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain, fatigue, and fever. Examination reveals joint swelling and inflammation. Laboratory studies show elevated inflammatory markers and autoantibodies. Diagnosis: Rheumatoid arthritis flare.
transcription: Patient: A 45-year-old female presented to the rheumatology clinic with complaints of joint pain, fatigue, and fever. She has a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, which she has been managing with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and biologic therapy for the past 10 years. Her symptoms have been worsening over the past month, and she has been experiencing morning stiffness, joint swelling, and pain in multiple joints, including the hands, wrists, knees, and feet. She has also noticed a low-grade fever and fatigue. Physical examination revealed joint swelling and inflammation in the hands, wrists, and knees. Laboratory studies were significant for elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) of 3.5 mg/L (normal < 0.5 mg/L) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 60 mm/h (normal < 20 mm/h), as well as positive rheumatoid factor (RF) and anticyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. Radiographs showed joint space narrowing and erosions in the hands and knees, consistent with chronic rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings were consistent with a flare of her rheumatoid arthritis, and her DMARD and biologic therapy were optimized.

description: A 55-year-old female with a 2-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain and stiffness.
transcription: Patient: A 55-year-old female presents with a 2-year history of rheumatoid arthritis. She complains of joint pain and stiffness, primarily affecting her hands and feet. The patient reports some difficulty with daily activities as a result. She denies fevers, weight loss, or night sweats. The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism, both well-controlled with medication. The patient is not taking any medications related to her rheumatoid arthritis at this time. Physical Exam: The patient appears uncomfortable but in no acute distress. Her vital signs are stable. Her joint exam is significant for swelling, warmth, and tenderness in multiple joints, including the MCP and PIP joints of the hands and the MTP joints of the feet. There is also some limitation of motion in these joints. X-rays of the hands and feet were obtained and reveal some erosive changes and joint space narrowing, consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Laboratory studies are notable for an elevated ESR (51 mm/hr) and RF (87 IU/ml). Recommendation: Continuation of methotrexate at 15 mg weekly, with initiation of a biologic agent, such as etanercept or adalimumab.

description: A patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain and swelling. The rheumatologist performs a physical examination and orders laboratory tests to evaluate inflammatory markers. The patient is prescribed a course of corticosteroids and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs).
transcription: Patient presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and swelling, predominantly in the hands and feet. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, diagnosed 5 years ago, and has been managed with methotrexate and prednisone. The patient reports some relief with these medications, but the symptoms have been worsening over the past few months. On examination, the patient has bilateral synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal joints, with tenderness and swelling. The patient also has synovitis of the wrists and proximal interphalangeal joints. Laboratory tests show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 64 mm/h and a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 4.5 mg/L. The patient is prescribed a course of prednisone 40 mg daily for 1 month, with tapering doses over the following 6 months. The patient is also started on methotrexate 25 mg weekly, with folic acid 1 mg daily as a folic acid antidote. The patient is instructed to follow up in 6 months for reassessment.
sample_name: Joint Pain and Swelling in a Patient with Rheumatoid Arthritis

description: Case presentation of a 71-year-old female with symptoms of joint pain and stiffness. Diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis confirmed through laboratory tests and imaging. Treatment plan includes disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
transcription: 71-year-old female presenting with symptoms of joint pain and stiffness. Patient reports morning stiffness lasting approximately 30 minutes in both the hands and feet, as well as pain and swelling in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the hands. Pain is described as aching and is worse in the mornings and after periods of inactivity. Patient denies fever, weight loss, or malaise. Past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include levothyroxine, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and acetaminophen as needed for pain. Physical examination reveals 10/14 joint line tenderness in the hands and 3/6 joint line tenderness in the feet. Joints are not warm or swollen. Laboratory studies include a C-reactive protein of 1.6 mg/L (reference range 0-1.0 mg/L), erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 44 mm/h (reference range 0-15 mm/h), and rheumatoid factor of 61 IU/mL (reference range 0-14 IU/mL). Antinuclear antibody is negative. Radiographs of the hands and feet reveal erosions and joint space narrowing consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made. Treatment plan includes disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as methotrexate or leflunomide, as well as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen for pain management.
sample_name: Rheumatoid Arthritis in an Elderly Female

description: Consultation with speech-language pathologist for assessment and treatment of communication and swallowing disorders in adults and children.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up speech therapy. Today we will work on articulation drills for words ending in s, sh, ch, and x. We will also practice reading aloud with emphasis on intonation and expression. Regarding swallowing, the patient reports no issues with solid or liquid foods. We will continue with regular therapy sessions as prescribed.

description: Consultation for a 64-year-old male with aphasia and dysarthria following a cerebrovascular accident. Discussion of cognitive, language, and speech therapy options.
transcription: Consultation with Dr. Smith today. The patient is a 64-year-old male who presented with aphasia and dysarthria following a cerebrovascular accident. We discussed his cognitive, language, and speech therapy options.

description: Consultation for a 28-year-old male with a history of developmental language disorder and speech impairment. The patient presents with dysfluency, atypical prosody, and difficulties with word retrieval. He reports symptoms of anxiety and fatigue, which may be contributing factors. Recommendations include speech therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy for anxiety, and stress management techniques.
transcription: Consultation with Dr. X for a 28-year-old male with a history of developmental language disorder and speech impairment. The patient presents with dysfluency, atypical prosody, and difficulties with word retrieval. He reports symptoms of anxiety and fatigue, which may be contributing factors. Dr. X recommends speech therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy for anxiety, and stress management techniques.

description: Consultation with a speech-language pathologist for evaluation and treatment of communication and swallowing disorders. Discussion of assessment results and development of a treatment plan.
transcription: Patient: Good morning. Doctor: Good morning, how may I help you today? Patient: I have some difficulties with speaking and swallowing. Doctor: Okay, we're here to help you with that. Today we'll be doing an evaluation to assess the nature and severity of your communication and swallowing difficulties. We'll then discuss the results with you and develop a treatment plan. Patient: Great, I'm looking forward to it.

description: Summary of a medical autopsy report
transcription: Autopsy Performed on: 07/10/2017, Time of Death: 15:45, Age: 81 Years, Cause of Death: Cardiac Arrest, Findings: Multiple Myeloma (Stage 3B), Atherosclerosis, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), Emphysema, Cardiomegaly, Atrial Fibrillation, Severe Atherosclerosis of Coronary Arteries, Left Ventricular Hypertrophy, Severe Calcification of Aortic Valve, Moderate Calcification of Mitral and Tricuspid Valves, Pleural Effusion, Ascites, Gross Weight: 58.00 Kg, Internal Organs: Heart weighs 460 grams, Liver weighs 1950 grams, Spleen weighs 85 grams, Lungs weigh 1100 grams, Kidneys weigh 380 grams each, Prostate weighs 35 grams, Thyroid weighs 14 grams, Pancreas weighs 85 grams, Stomach weighs 165 grams, Small Intestine weighs 1000 grams, Cecum weighs 20 grams, Large Intestine weighs 1100 grams, Appendix weighs 5 grams, Urinary Bladder weighs 115 grams, Gallbladder weighs 55 grams, Common Bile Duct measures 7 mm, Common Sheath of Nerves of Spinal Cord measures 10 mm, Vertebral Body measures 35 mm, Femur measures 330 mm, Tibia measures 295 mm, Spine measures 470 mm, Skull measures 580 mm, Body Length measures 1650 mm, Autopsy Performed By: [Signature], Autopsy Reviewed By: [Signature]
keywords: moderate calcification of mitral and tricuspid valves
common sheath of nerves of spinal cord

description: Examination of decedent's body for determination of cause and manner of death.
transcription: Autopsy Performed on: 3/12/2015 Time: 12:00 PM By: M. D. O. C. S. Decedent: Female, 86 years, 5 feet 4 inches, 134 pounds. Cause and Manner of Death: Chronic Dementia and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, Natural. Findings: 1. Atherosclerosis involving the aorta, coronary arteries, and cerebral vessels. 2. Cardiac: LVH, dilated left atrium, no dilation of right atrium or right ventricle, no pericardial or pleural effusion. 3. Respiratory: Residual bronchitis, emphysema, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 4. Gastrointestinal: Gastric atrophy, duodenal atrophy. 5. Genitourinary: Moderate atherosclerosis of renal arteries. 6. Musculoskeletal: Osteoarthritis involving the cervical and lumbar spine, bilateral hip joints, and left knee joint. 7. Skin: Actinic changes. 8. Toxicology: Therapeutic levels of: Carbamazepine, Levofloxacin, Furosemide, and Hydromorphone. Other: Cardiac pacemaker in situ.

description: Summary of a medical autopsy report
transcription: AUTOPSY REPORT 38445. This autopsy was performed on (DATE) on (DECEASED) (AGE) year (MONTH) and (DAY) month and (DAY) day, 20XX. This is to certify that this autopsy was performed by (SIGNATURE) and that this autopsy was performed for the purpose of educational or validating pathological diagnosis. The history of this deceased individual was as follows: (HISTORY). Autopsy findings: (FINDINGS). All organs and tissues were normal. The cause of death, as determined by this autopsy, is (CAUSE OF DEATH). Manner of death: (MANNER OF DEATH). Decalage: (DECALAGE). The decalage is (NUMBER) centimeters. The time of the autopsy was (TIME) postmortem. Autopsy was performed by (SIGNATURE).

description: Summary of a medical autopsy report
transcription: Autopsy performed on 56 year old male who died suddenly at home. Gross pathology reveals obesity, enlarged heart and lungs, and congestion of all organs. Microscopic examination confirms myocardial hypertrophy, pulmonary edema, and hypertensive arteriosclerosis. Cause of death is determined to be cardiac failure due to coronary artery disease.

description: Report on histopathological examination of lymph node for suspected lymphoma.
transcription: Histopathologic examination of a lymph node revealed a diffuse infiltrate of small lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm. Mitotic figures were identified. The immunohistochemical profile was consistent with a B cell lymphoma, most likely a follicular lymphoma, grade 2.

description: Report on histopathological examination of tissue specimen.
transcription: Histopathology of a 1.0 x 0.7 x 0.6 cm section of the right breast shows proliferation of epithelial cells with elongated nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The epithelial cells are arranged in a cribriform pattern with small lumina. The tissue stains strongly with estrogen receptor. The histopathologic features are consistent with invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, ER positive, PR negative, HER2 negative.

description: Results of biopsy of left breast. Carcinoma, infiltrating ductal, 2.0 cm, Grade II, ER/PR+, HER2-
transcription: BREAST, LEFT - BIOPSY: 11/24/2011: CARCINOMA, INFILTRATING DUCTAL, 2.0 CM, GRADING SYSTEM II, ESTROGEN RECEPTOR AND PROGESTERONE RECEPTOR POSITIVE, HER2 NEGATIVE

description: Report on biopsy of liver for evaluation of possible primary hepatoma. Lesion shows features consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma.
transcription: PATHOLGY DEPARTMENT REPORT #: 4176 DATE: 11/20/2018 15:07 4176 11/20/2018 03:07 PATHOLOGY REQ'D BY: BURNS, JASON L. SPECIMEN IDENTIFICATION: Liver. Biopsy. 1 tissue cassette. RECEIVED: 11/20/2018 ORIGINAL DIAGNOSIS: Biopsy for evaluation of possible primary hepatoma. GROSS DESCRIPTION: One (1) tissue cassette received for microscopic examination. NET REQUIREMENTS: Four (4) unstained glass slides. STATUS: Fully processed. DIAGNOSIS: Lesion shows features consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma. MORPHOLOGY: Section shows a well-defined nodular lesion within the liver parenchyma, comprised of enlarged pleomorphic hepatocytes with prominent macronucleoli and prominent nuclear pseudoinclusions. The lesion shows areas of necrosis. MITOSES: Multiple atypical mitotic figures are present. INTERPRETATION: Lesion shows features consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma.
sample_name: Liver Biopsy for Evaluation of Possible Primary Hepatoma

description: Evaluation of thyroid tissue for the presence of follicular neoplasms and Hurthle cell neoplasms. Additional studies for follicular neoplasms: Thyroidobulin, Galicia stain, and molecular genetic analysis for BRAF mutations.
transcription: (1) Thyroid tissue. 1. Right lobe, 4.5 cm x 2.7 cm x 2.5 cm. 2. Left lobe, 6.5 cm x 3.2 cm x 2.7 cm. (2) Sections show multiple, variably sized, follicular neoplasms, some with macrofollicles. Some areas show Hurthle cells and oncocytic features. (3) Thyroidobulin: Focally increased in some follicles in the right lobe. (4) Galicia stain: Negative. (5) Molecular genetic analysis for BRAF mutations: Negative. (6) No features of malignancy.

description: Evaluation of bone marrow biopsy for morphology and immunophenotyping in a 69 year old male with suspected myelodysplastic syndrome.
transcription: Bone marrow biopsy received for evaluation. Marrow is hypercellular with left shift and erythroid hyperplasia. There is a prominent megakaryocyte population. Flow cytometry performed and shows the following: 94% of cells are monoclonal. 91% of cells are CD34 positive. 98% of cells are CD19 negative. 96% of cells are CD13 positive. 99% of cells are CD38 positive. 97% of cells are CD56 negative. 98% of cells are CD45 positive. 99% of cells are sIg negative. 98% of cells are HLA-DR positive. 99% of cells are cyCD3 positive. 98% of cells are CD14 negative. 97% of cells are CD20 negative. 99% of cells are CD28 negative. 98% of cells are CD2 negative. 98% of cells are CD5 negative. 98% of cells are CD11c negative. 98% of cells are CD11b negative. 99% of cells are CD16 negative. 99% of cells are CD56 negative. 99% of cells are CD19 negative. 98% of cells are CD22 negative. 98% of cells are CD25 negative. 98% of cells are FMC7 negative. 99% of cells are Kappa negative. 99% of cells are Lambda negative. 99% of cells are CD3 negative. 98% of cells are CD7 negative. 99% of cells are CD15 negative. 98% of cells are TdT negative. Based on these findings, the diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome is supported. The cytogenetics report is pending.

description: Evaluation of tissue sample for detection of malignant cells.
transcription: Pathology report: Right lower quadrant mass, tissue specimen. Sectioned and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Tissue architecture is preserved. Epithelial cells with enlarged nuclei and irregular contours are present in a background of inflammatory cells and fibrosis. These cells are consistent with adenocarcinoma. Malignant cells are present in 75% of the tissue section.
sample_name: Right Lower Quadrant Mass, Tissue Specimen

description: Patient presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis and asthma. Diagnosis of allergic rhinitis and asthma is confirmed through medical history and allergy testing. Patient is prescribed antihistamines and inhaled corticosteroids for symptom management.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up today for management of allergic rhinitis and asthma. The patient reports intermittent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and postnasal drip. The patient also reports intermittent shortness of breath with exertion, which is relieved with the use of albuterol. The patient denies any acute respiratory symptoms. The patient reports using nasal saline irrigation daily for nasal congestion. The patient reports taking loratadine 10mg daily for rhinitis. The patient reports using albuterol as needed for asthma. The patient denies any other relevant medical history. Allergies: Seasonal pollens, dust, and animal dander. Family history: Mother has asthma. Physical exam: Vital signs within normal limits. HEENT: Ears 2 and 2, nose 2 and 0, mouth 2 and 0, throat 2 and 0. Chest: Lungs clear to auscultation and percussion, no wheezing. Abdomen: Soft, nondistended, bowel sounds present. Extremities: 2 and 0. Neurologic: Alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Diagnosis: Allergic rhinitis, asthma. Recommendations: Continue use of nasal saline irrigation daily for rhinitis. Continue use of loratadine 10mg daily for rhinitis. Continue use of albuterol as needed for asthma. Consider adding an inhaled corticosteroid for asthma management.

description: Patient presents with recurrent hives and suspected food allergies. Diagnostic tests for common allergens are recommended. Prescription for antihistamines and epinephrine is provided for self-management of acute symptoms.
transcription: Patient presents for follow-up regarding their allergies. The patient reports having recurrent hives that have been persisting for the past several weeks. The patient suspects that these hives may be related to food allergies, as they have occurred following the consumption of certain foods. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient's medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical examination is unremarkable. Diagnostic tests for common allergens, such as peanuts, tree nuts, milk, soy, eggs, wheat, and fish, are recommended to confirm the presence of food allergies. Prescription for antihistamines, such as cetirizine or loratadine, is provided for self-management of mild to moderate symptoms. Prescription for epinephrine auto-injector is provided for self-management of acute symptoms, such as anaphylaxis. The patient is educated on the proper use of epinephrine and is instructed to seek immediate medical attention following its use.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of seasonal allergies. Diagnosis confirmed with skin prick test. Prescribed antihistamines and nasal steroids.
transcription: Patient presented to the clinic today complaining of seasonal allergy symptoms. The patient reports itching and watery eyes, sneezing, and a runny nose. On examination, the patient's nasal mucosa is clear and there is no discharge. The patient's conjunctiva is slightly injected. The patient reports a history of seasonal allergies for several years. A skin prick test was performed using a battery of common allergens. The patient demonstrated a positive response to tree pollens and grass pollens. Based on these findings, the patient has been diagnosed with seasonal allergies. The patient has been prescribed antihistamines and nasal steroids to manage their symptoms.

description: A 35-year-old female presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis, conjunctivitis, and asthma. Allergic workup is ordered.
transcription: 35-year-old female presents to the clinic today with complaints of allergic symptoms. She reports seasonal allergies that worsen in the spring and summer, with symptoms of sneezing, rhinorrhea, and itchy eyes. She has also been experiencing intermittent asthma symptoms for the past few weeks, with shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient reports no other relevant medical history. Physical exam is unremarkable. Allergic workup is ordered, including skin prick testing and serum IgE levels.

description: Patient presents with recurrent allergic reactions to pollen and pet dander.
transcription: Patient is a 32-year-old male with a history of seasonal allergies, primarily to pollen. He reports intermittent symptoms including rhinorrhea, sneezing, and itchy eyes. He has also been experiencing symptoms year-round due to exposure to pet dander at his wife's home, including itchy eyes and throat. He denies any other significant symptoms or pertinent medical history. Physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis: seasonal allergic rhinitis, perennial allergic rhinitis.

description: Patient presents with symptoms of hives and itching. Skin prick test reveals allergies to dust mites and tree pollen. Prescribed antihistamines and steroids for management.
transcription: Patient presents to the clinic today with complaints of hives and intense itching. The patient reports that the symptoms began approximately 2 weeks ago and have been worsening in severity since. The patient denies any associated fever, malaise, or other systemic symptoms. The patient reports no recent exposure to new environments or allergens. On physical exam, the patient has numerous urticarial lesions over the trunk, extremities, and face. There are no mucosal or ocular symptoms. The patient has no personal or family history of atopy or hives. The patient has not recently taken any new medications or supplements. A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are ordered and found to be within normal limits. A skin prick test is performed to evaluate for common allergens. The test reveals a 4mmx4mm wheal at 12 hours with dust mite extract and a 3mmx3mm wheal at 12 hours with tree pollen extract. The patient is diagnosed with allergic rhinitis and cutaneous mastocytosis. The patient is prescribed cetirizine 10mg daily and prednisone 30mg daily for 5 days for management of symptoms.

description: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of asthma, seasonal allergies, and allergic rhinitis. He reports experiencing increased symptoms over the past two weeks, including coughing and wheezing. The patient is prescribed a short course of prednisone and an inhaler for symptomatic relief.
transcription: Patient is a 28-year-old male, presenting with a history of asthma, seasonal allergies, and allergic rhinitis. He reports experiencing increased symptoms over the past two weeks, including coughing and wheezing. Physical examination is unremarkable. Labs are pending. ECG is normal. CXR is unremarkable. Management: Patient is prescribed a short course of prednisone and an inhaler for symptomatic relief.

description: A patient presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. Diagnosis is confirmed with skin prick testing. Treatment with antihistamines and nasal steroids is prescribed.
transcription:
Date: 03/25/2021
Patient: John Doe

Chief Complaint: Allergies

History: The patient reports seasonal allergies with symptoms of sneezing, itchy eyes, and a runny nose. He also reports year-round allergies with symptoms of itchy eyes and a runny nose. The patient has tried over-the-counter antihistamines but they do not help.

Exam: The patient's nasal mucosa is mildly erythematous. His conjunctiva is mildly injected. There is clear rhinorrhea.

Diagnosis: Allergic rhinitis

Treatment: Antihistamines and nasal steroids will be prescribed.

Follow-up: The patient will return in 2 weeks to assess symptom improvement.

Notes: Skin prick testing was performed and revealed positive reactions to Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus, Blomia tropicalis, and Alternaria alternata.

description: Patient is receiving palliative care for end-stage cancer. Symptom management includes pain control, nutritional support, and emotional and spiritual care. Family is being provided with counseling and support.
transcription:
Hospice Visit - 05/23/2021

Patient: Mrs. Jane Doe
Age: 75
Diagnosis: End-Stage Cancer (Lung)

Visiting Nurse: Sarah Smith, RN

Visit Summary:
Patient is receiving hospice care for end-stage cancer. She is in moderate pain, controlled with morphine 15mg PO q4hr PRN. She is NPO due to nausea and decreased appetite. She is receiving 1000mg IV hydration qd for dehydration. She is also receiving haloperidol 5mg PRN for agitation. Her nutrition is being managed with a blenderized diet. Her family is being provided with emotional and spiritual support. Her husband is being counseled for depression and anxiety. Her daughter is being counseled for grief and loss issues. The family is receiving education regarding symptom management, medication management, and wound care. They are being encouraged to participate in her care, including bathing, grooming, and positioning. The family reports that they are satisfied with the care provided by hospice. They report that the patient is comfortable, and that she is able to communicate and interact with them. They report that they are being provided with emotional and spiritual support, and that they feel well-informed and supported.
sample_name: Hospice Visit for Mrs. Jane Doe

description: End-of-life care for patients with terminal illnesses
transcription: [Patient Name] is a [Age] year old female with a history of [Disease], who has been under our care since [Date]. The patient is currently receiving [Treatment] as part of her hospice care. Her family has requested that we continue to manage her pain and symptoms, while allowing her to remain at home for the duration of her illness. We will be providing regular visits from our palliative care team to monitor her condition and provide necessary interventions. [Patient Name]'s prognosis is [Prognosis], and we will continue to provide compassionate care and support throughout her remaining days.
sample_name: End-of-Life Care for Patient with Advanced Cancer
